Service
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Service** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A positive outcome of practice. As your practice reduces your own suffering, you may be inspired to contribute to the lives of others. Pairs with the personal benefits you get from practice. 2. A motivation to practice. You may practice because you want to contribute more to the lives of others. Complements the work you do on yourself for yourself. |
| **Synonyms** | [Serve from Love](/index.php/Serve_from_Love "Serve from Love") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Magic Presence](/index.php?title=Magic_Presence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Magic Presence (page does not exist)") |

Flooding
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Flooding** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A practice challenge (wall) in which there is a lot of activation in one or more sense categories, and you feel overwhelmed by the experience. If a challenge is reported when first learning the See Hear Feel technique, this is the most commonly reported one. |
| **Synonyms** | [Overwhelm](/index.php/Overwhelm "Overwhelm"), [Sensory Overwhelm](/index.php/Sensory_Overwhelm "Sensory Overwhelm") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** |  |

Microhit
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Microhit** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A type of informal practice described in UM that involves dedicating your attention to a mindfulness technique for less than 10 minutes. Can be as short as just a few seconds. |

| **Antonyms** |  |

Sensory Clarity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Sensory Clarity
===============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Sensory Clarity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the three core attention skills, the ability to track and explore sensory experience in real time. Has two sides: Detection (sensitivity to details) and Discernment (the ability to tell this from that, such as the distinction between See and Hear and Feel). |
| **Synonyms** | [Clarity](/index.php/Clarity "Clarity") |
| **Antonyms** | [Unconsciousness](/index.php?title=Unconsciousness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Unconsciousness (page does not exist)") |
| **Related** | [Detection](/index.php?title=Detection&action=edit&redlink=1 "Detection (page does not exist)"), [Discernment](/index.php?title=Discernment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Discernment (page does not exist)") |

Feel Rest - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Feel Rest
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Feel Rest** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on restful body experience, including physical relaxation, absence of body sensation, and Emotional Peace (i.e., the absence of sensations you recognize as being emotional). (See Emotional Peace) 2. Shorthand for restful experience in Feel. |
| **Synonyms** | [Stillness](/index.php/Stillness "Stillness") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Emotional Peace](/index.php/Emotional_Peace "Emotional Peace"), [Just Feel](/index.php/Just_Feel "Just Feel"), [See Rest](/index.php/See_Rest "See Rest"), [Hear Rest](/index.php/Hear_Rest "Hear Rest"), [Appreciate](/index.php/Appreciate "Appreciate") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Feel_Rest&oldid=2189>"

Hear Out - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Hear Out
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Hear Out** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on physical sound (active) and physical silence or the silence around or through sound (restful). 2. Short for the space where you detect physical sound or silence, or what you hear in the environment, whether active or restful. For example, when guiding someone you say, *Bring your attention to Hear Out, sound or silence in your environment*. |
| **Synonyms** | [Hear Out space](/index.php/Hear_Out_space "Hear Out space") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** |  |

Deconstruct - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Deconstruct
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Deconstruct** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A focus strategy that involves identifying the sensory building blocks or parts of a given experience. This has two effects: It reduces the suffering associated with uncomfortable experiences and reduces the somethingness associated with any and all experience, helping to deepen happiness altogether. The building blocks could be broad, such as See, Hear, and Feel, or they could be more narrow, such as the combination of Anger and Shame in an emotional state. |
| **Synonyms** | [Divide and Conquer](/index.php/Divide_and_Conquer "Divide and Conquer"), [Untangle and Unblock](/index.php/Untangle_and_Unblock "Untangle and Unblock"), [Untangle and Be Free](/index.php/Untangle_and_Be_Free "Untangle and Be Free") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Work with the Parts](/index.php?title=Work_with_the_Parts&action=edit&redlink=1 "Work with the Parts (page does not exist)"), [Work with the Whole strategy](/index.php?title=Work_with_the_Whole_strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Work with the Whole strategy (page does not exist)"), [Flooding](/index.php/Flooding "Flooding"), [Discernment](/index.php?title=Discernment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Discernment (page does not exist)"), [strands or components (i.e.](/index.php?title=Strands_or_components_(i.e.&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strands or components (i.e. (page does not exist)"), [parts)](/index.php?title=Parts)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Parts) (page does not exist)"), [reification (neuroscience)](/index.php?title=Reification_(neuroscience)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Reification (neuroscience) (page does not exist)"), [Sensory Clarity](/index.php/Sensory_Clarity "Sensory Clarity"), [Integration Strategies (Self CARE)](/index.php?title=Integration_Strategies_(Self_CARE)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Integration Strategies (Self CARE) (page does not exist)") |

Fulfillment - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Fulfillment
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Fulfillment** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The second column on UM’s Happiness Grid, this happiness type centers around the pursuit of satisfaction or comfort through pleasant situations and experiences. As with all items on the Happiness Grid, this refers both to the impact of a practice on fulfillment and the impact of other factors such as purposeful action, chance, and so forth. The four levels of Fulfillment are:  1. You can get situations to go the way you want 2. You can have pleasant sensory experiences 3. You can be skillful with pleasant sensory experiences 4. You can completely experience pleasant sensory experiences |
| **Synonyms** | [Elevate Fulfillment](/index.php/Elevate_Fulfillment "Elevate Fulfillment") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Relief](/index.php/Relief "Relief"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Mastery](/index.php/Mastery "Mastery"), [Connection](/index.php/Connection "Connection"), [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Happiness Types](/index.php/Happiness_Types "Happiness Types"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification") |

Insight - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Insight
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Insight** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Understandings, meaningful experiences, or “aha” moments that come about as the result of practice. This is a broad definition of the word insight that can be used in many situations. The term Insight, referring to a column of the Happiness Grid, has a more specialized definition.  Can be understood as happening on a continuum from surface to deep:   * Surface Insight—you’re looking to satisfy more ordinary happiness conditions. For instance, you figure out how to win at poker. * Deeper Insight—you’ve begun to understand insight in a broader, more complete way. For instance, the pain you’re experiencing doesn’t need to go away, the sensations just need to move without running into any resistance. Other insights would be clearly seeing how CC&E work together to minimize suffering or how they work together to amplify fulfillment. * Deep Insight—you discover what it’s like to completely transcend the need for more surface outcomes. For instance, through direct experience you’re released from a sense of separateness. As a result, you realize that getting stuck in a sense of separateness is what causes you to suffer. Other insights include experiential understanding of deep Expansion/Contraction flow, Original Completeness, how Serving From Love is a natural consequence of Oneness, etc. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Wisdom Function](/index.php?title=Wisdom_Function&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wisdom Function (page does not exist)"), [Original Completeness](/index.php?title=Original_Completeness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Original Completeness (page does not exist)"), [Expansion/Contraction](/index.php?title=Expansion/Contraction&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expansion/Contraction (page does not exist)"), [Spontaneity](/index.php/Spontaneity "Spontaneity") |

Sensory Challenges & Adverse Reactions - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Sensory Challenges & Adverse Reactions
======================================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Sensory Challenges & Adverse Reactions** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Destabilizing, unexpected, and/or unpleasant sensory experiences that happen as a result of mindfulness practice can range from mild to more intense. Even intense experiences are rarely serious and typically don’t last. They’re usually limited to sensory effects but can also involve motor or behavior changes. Self CARE strategies are recommended to prevent and correct. If they intersect with other issues such as mental health challenges, or they become persistent, supplements may be needed. By contrast, a true adverse reaction means that meditation itself has caused serious problems, such as hospitalization. When intense sensory experiences rise to the level of a true adverse reaction, which is rare, they require additional support, including possible emergency interventions, as well as the usual recommendations of consistent Self CARE routines and other supplements, where needed. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Supplements](/index.php?title=Supplements&action=edit&redlink=1 "Supplements (page does not exist)"), [Self CARE Integration Strategies](/index.php?title=Self_CARE_Integration_Strategies&action=edit&redlink=1 "Self CARE Integration Strategies (page does not exist)"), [Hedonic Valence](/index.php/Hedonic_Valence "Hedonic Feel Flow - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Feel Flow
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Feel Flow** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Transcend quadrant in which you’re focusing attention on any perception of movement, change, or energy in body sensations. 2. Short for flowing experience in Feel. |

Image Space
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Image Space** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The location where you may detect mental image activity or inner visual rest. Generally located in front of or behind the physical eyes—where it’s often called the “mental screen”—and may extend in other directions as well, including where the body is located, or the space corresponding to the surrounding environment. Taken together, these three are known as “Image Space.” |
| **Synonyms** | [Mental Image Space](/index.php/Mental_Image_Space "Mental Image Space") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See In](/index.php/See_In "See In"), [Hear In](/index.php/Hear_In "Hear In"), [Mental Talk Space](/index.php?title=Mental_Talk_Space&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mental Talk Space (page does not exist)"), [Mental Screen](/index.php?title=Mental_Screen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mental Screen (page does not exist)"), [Mental Stage](/index.php?title=Mental_Stage&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mental Stage (page does not exist)"), [Center of Image Space](/index.php?title=Center_of_Image_Space&action=edit&redlink=1 "Center of Image Space (page does not exist)") |

Spontaneity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Spontaneity
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Spontaneity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. The effortless just-happeningness of the spread and collapse of space at the deepest phase of sensory experience. You can be sensitized to it when CC&E Levels are lower, or you can experience it as transcendence through Expansion/Contraction Flow and/or the Bounce of Auto. In Unified Mindfulness, you can work with the theme of effortless self-organizing in two main ways: See Hear Feel Now for the Perception side and Auto Move, Speak, Think, Focus for the Expression side. 2. A deepening attainment. The effortless just-happening of experience known more consistently through deepening CC&E. |
| **Synonyms** | [Expansion/Contraction Flow](/index.php/Expansion/Contraction_Flow "Expansion/Contraction Flow") |
| **Antonyms** | [Control](/index.php?title=Control&action=edit&redlink=1 "Control (page does not exist)") |
| **Related** | [Expressiveness](/index.php?title=Expressiveness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expressiveness (page does not exist)"), [Express (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Express_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Express (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Transcend (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Transcend_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcend (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [SHF Now](/index.php?title=SHF_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF Now (page does not exist)"), [Auto Move](/index.php/Auto_Move "Auto Move"), [Auto Speak](/index.php?title=Auto_Speak&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Speak (page does not exist)"), [Auto Think](/index.php?title=Auto_Think&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Think (page does not exist)"), [Do Nothing](/index.php/Do_Nothing "Do Nothing"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Integration Strategies (Self CARE)](/index.php?title=Integration_Strategies_(Self_CARE)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Integration Strategies (Self CARE) (page does not exist)"), [Bounce](/index.php?title=Bounce&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bounce (page does not exist)") |

Labeling
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Labeling** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A technique option used to support noting; it typically involves thinking or saying aloud a word or phrase to describe what you’re noting; aids in the continuous application of CC&E. The word or phrase is expressed in a matter of fact tone of voice and may be experienced at different intensities internally or externally—mentally, mouthed or whispered, spoken, spoken strongly—or dropped entirely, based on the state of a person's skills at a given time. It can also be done by tapping your fingers instead of using words. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Noting](/index.php/Noting "Noting"), [Flexible Labels](/index.php?title=Flexible_Labels&action=edit&redlink=1 "Flexible Labels (page does not exist)") |

See In
======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See In** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on inner visual experience, whether active like mental images, or restful, like a blank mental screen. 2. Short for the space where you detect inner visual experience, or what you see in the mind, whether active or restful. For example, as you guide a technique, you might say, Now with your eyes open or closed, bring your attention to See In, the place where you may detect mental images or inner visual rest. |
| **Synonyms** | [Image Space](/index.php/Image_Space "Image Space"), [See In Space](/index.php/See_In_Space "See In Space") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Mental images](/index.php?title=Mental_images&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mental images (page does not exist)"), [grayscale](/index.php/Grayscale "Grayscale"), [blank mental screen](/index.php?title=Blank_mental_screen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Blank mental screen (page does not exist)"), [visual rest](/index.php?title=Visual_rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Visual rest (page does not exist)") |

Just Note New/Gone - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Just Note New/Gone
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Just Note New/Gone** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A Special Exercise in the Transcend quadrant which can be thought of from two main points of view:  1. It’s commonly a warm-up for SHF Now because it can be easier to practice. Focuses on two complementary kinds of split-second Expansion/Contraction flow:  * **New:** The instant you become aware of an experience—whether the experience is beginning and you notice that as it happens, or your attention makes fresh contact with an experience that is already happening. * **Gone:** The instant you become aware that an experience is partially or completely ending, whether you’re clear about what the experience is or not.  2. It’s also a Direct Pointing technique which takes the Absolute as its focus range. While Expansion/Contraction is Space based (Contour of E/C Flow), New/Gone is time based (beginnings and endings happen *Now*).   Highlights the Absolute in the following ways:   * New points to what experience is like when there’s no friction in the sensory system (Absolute Activity). Gone points to how experience comes together and resolves into nothingness (Absolute Rest). * New and Gone are always available, which points to Timelessness. If experience is always starting and stopping at the same time, then there is no timeline. It’s always (Absolute) Now. * When New is continuous, that’s another way to understand Expansion. When Gone is continuous, that’s another way to understand Contraction. |
| **Synonyms** | [Arising/Passing](/index.php/Arising/Passing "Arising/Passing") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Gone](/index.php/Gone "Gone"), [Expansion/Contraction](/index.php?title=Expansion/Contraction&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expansion/Contraction (page does not exist)"), [Transcend (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Transcend_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcend (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Special Exercise](/index.php/Special_Exercise "Special Exercise"), [SHF Now](/index.php?title=SHF_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF Now (page does not exist)"), [Direct Pointing](/index.php?title=Direct_Pointing&action=edit&redlink=1 "Direct Pointing (page does not exist)"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow") |

See Out
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See Out** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention primarily on outer visual experience such as objects in your environment, but also includes the possibility of outer visual rest, such as the soft gaze. 2. Short for the space where you detect outer visual experience, or what you see physically in the environment, whether active or restful. For instance, delivering a guided practice you might say, Bring your attention to See Out, visual experience with eyes open. |

| **Term** | **Hedonic Valence** |

See Hear Feel Back - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


See Hear Feel Back
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See Hear Feel Back** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A direct pointing technique in the Transcend Quadrant of the ULTRA Grid. The Focus Method is *Point*. As you freely float attention among See, Hear, and Feel you briefly point your attention backwards from sense experience you detect in the direction it came from. In UM, some pointing techniques are also Noting techniques. But, Turn Back is not a Noting technique. You don’t focus on anything and there is no time to acknowledge experience. You just reverse attention from whatever experience it meets. |
| **Synonyms** | [Turn Back](/index.php/Turn_Back "Turn Back") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Witness](/index.php?title=Witness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Witness (page does not exist)"), [Non-Dual](/index.php?title=Non-Dual&action=edit&redlink=1 "Non-Dual (page does not exist)"), [Koan](/index.php?title=Koan&action=edit&redlink=1 "Koan (page does not exist)"), [Aware of Aware](/index.php?title=Aware_of_Aware&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aware of Aware (page does not exist)") |

Connection - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Connection
==========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Connection** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The fifth column on UM’s Happiness Grid, this happiness type covers all the ways people find meaning or satisfaction through forming relationships, overcoming isolation, and/or experiencing Oneness as the source of connection. Includes the following levels:   1. Your relationships make you happy (e.g., personal, professional, pets, social). 2. You help others achieve happiness (e.g., through parenting, caregiving, mentoring, service). 3. You connect through subtle teaching (e.g., you’re a role model, have good energy, love unconditionally). 4. You make a universal connection by teaching others to develop happiness independent of conditions.   Covers two distinct features of your happiness goals:   * Whether you’re seeking connection through what your relationships bring to your life, or whether you’re seeking it through helping others find happiness. This can be thought of as the scale of your happiness goal. Does your goal scale beyond just yourself? * Whether you’re clearly aware of Oneness as the source of connection or not. Levels 3 and Level 4 highlight Oneness. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Love](/index.php/Love "Love"), [Service (former term)](/index.php?title=Service_(former_term)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Service (former term) (page does not exist)"), [Unconditional Love](/index.php?title=Unconditional_Love&action=edit&redlink=1 "Unconditional Love (page does not exist)"), [Transpersonal](/index.php?title=Transpersonal&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transpersonal (page does not exist)"), [Magic Presence](/index.php?title=Magic_Presence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Magic Presence (page does not exist)"), [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Relief](/index.php/Relief "Relief"), [Fulfillment](/index.php/Fulfillment "Fulfillment"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Mastery](/index.php/Mastery "Mastery"), [Support](/index.php/Support "Support") |

Turn Toward - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Turn Toward
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Turn Toward** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A UM focus strategy in which you intentionally place attention on and open up to a sensory experience. Often used to work directly with unpleasant experience (walls) but may also be applied to pleasant experience (windows). As you apply this strategy, you untangle experience through Clarity, unblock it through Equanimity, and—if you’re taking an active stance during noting—you soak into the experience through the intense focus of high Concentration coupled with enhanced sensory detection. Pairs with Anchor Away. |
| **Synonyms** | [Open up and turn toward](/index.php/Open_up_and_turn_toward "Open up and turn toward") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away") |

Absolute Activity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Absolute Activity
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Absolute Activity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. **A Temporary Sensory State:** The Perception of Formlessness as Form. A temporary perception of Absolute Rest (formlessness) as form. What mainly registers in the senses is Oneness, or Non-separateness, as two fused opposite equal activities of expansion and contraction. Even though there is still the perception of form, the senses are fully engaged in the expanding and contracting activity shaping all experience. There is no sense of a separate self and very little somethingness is perceived in the activity, which can be relatively more restful or more active. The *Activity* of Absolute Activity is just a way to say that the senses are perceiving form, as compared to the total formlessness of our primary definition of Absolute Rest. You could say that Absolute Activity is Absolute Rest as deep Expansion/Contraction Flow. In a transcendent state of Absolute Activity, instead of Expansion/Contraction Flow canceling out to no form at all, what registers in consciousness is the complete uniformity of form.   The term is defined by certain key relationships:   * **Deep, all-encompassing Expansion/Contraction Flow, as opposed to localized Expansion/Contraction Flow.**   + **A Unifying Sensory Theme.** As opposed to Expansion/Contraction experienced as just a *kind* of Flow, whether vibratory or ordinary, (e.g., a noticeable pushing out and pulling in, for instance, in your abdomen), Deep Expansion/Contraction Flow means that *all* of sensory perception is *only* Expansion/Contraction Flow. When that happens in perception there is no longer a *thing* called Expansion/Contraction Flow. It’s the way of all experience.   + **A Spatially Oriented Description of Transcendence.** Descriptions of E/C Flow tend to highlight the spatial aspects of experience. For example, the effortless expanding and collapsing of the two opposite equal forces that mold all experience cover the whole space of awareness. There isn’t any *location* where E/C Flow is not. * **The Deepest Phase of *Perception* as opposed to *Expression*.** When talking aboutthe Absolute, a way to discuss just the perception side of formless form (by contrast, the term Absolute Now includes both perception and expression). Technically, Perception and Expression are both sensory experiences and in transcendence there is no separateness between them. So, depending on what stood out to you, you could use Deep Spontaneity as a synonym for Deep E/C Flow. But for the purpose of gaining clarity, it can be useful to talk about perception and expression independently. Deep E/C Flow (aka, Absolute Activity) is UM’s way of describing how formlessness is fully revealed in the perception of form (bearing in mind that there is no separate *perceiver*).  2. **A Deepening Attainment.** When your baseline of CC&E is consistently high, as a default, the sensory system is operating with much less friction. So Absolute Activity rules perception, whether sensory experience is active or restful. As a result of practice, this happens more consistently. 3. **A Sensory Trait: The Theme Underlying All Perception.** Absolute Activity is ever present, at least as a sensory potential. So, any perception of Expansion/Contraction at any phase of experience can be understood as accessing the base level trait of perception, even just as an incomplete glimpse. |
| **Synonyms** | [Deep Expansion/Contraction Flow](/index.php/Deep_Expansion/Contraction_Flow "Deep Expansion/Contraction Flow") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Absolute](/index.php/Absolute "Absolute"), [Absolute Rest](/index.php/Absolute_Rest "Absolute Rest"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now"), [Transcendence](/index.php?title=Transcendence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcendence (page does not exist)"), [See Now](/index.php?title=See_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "See Now (page does not exist)"), [Hear Now](/index.php?title=Hear_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hear Now (page does not exist)"), [Feel Now](/index.php?title=Feel_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "Feel Now (page does not exist)"), [SHF Now](/index.php?title=SHF_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF Now (page does not exist)"), [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [Aspect-Phase-Level](/index.php/Aspect-Phase-Level "Aspect-Phase-Level"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows") |

Momentum Practice - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Momentum Practice
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Momentum Practice** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The carry-over from past practice that has an effect on your present moment experience when you’re not intentionally trying to practice. Anyone with a mindfulness practice enjoys this benefit. Once you start a mindfulness practice, at any given instant, you’ll be doing one of four kinds of practice: 1) Formal Practice, 2) Background Practice, 3) Microhits, 4) Momentum Practice. |

Support
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Support** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. Anything or anyone who acts as a direct resource—people, places, or things—for applying and developing mindful awareness, and ultimately, practice maturity. For example, meeting with a Trainer, practicing with a community, or using an app. Covers two of the Four Pillars of Practice, Get Support and Give Support. 2. (Self) The internalized skill of guiding your own practice. An aspect of Trait Mindfulness that involves following your instincts about how to develop mindfulness and apply it well in life situations. Learning how to support others can also help you be better at doing this for yourself in your own practice. |
| **Synonyms** | [Support for Practice](/index.php/Support_for_Practice "Support for Practice") |

Concentration - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Concentration
=============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Concentration** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the three core attention skills, the ability to focus on what you choose when you want to. You can think of it as a kind of flexible focus. Can be developed by focusing on a small or large object of focus, and for a short or long period of time. Can be developed by keeping your focus within a focus range for as long as possible (sustained concentration), or by focusing for brief moments on one or more sensory experiences within a focus range (momentary concentration). |
| **Synonyms** | [Concentration Power](/index.php/Concentration_Power "Concentration Power"), [Focus](/index.php/Focus "Focus"), [Concentrate (verb)](/index.php/Concentrate_(verb) "Concentrate (verb)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Clarity](/index.php/Clarity "Clarity"), [Equanimity](/index.php/Equanimity "Equanimity"), [Contact Strategy](/index.php?title=Contact_Strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Contact Strategy (page does not exist)"), [Soak In](/index.php?title=Soak_In&action=edit&redlink=1 "Soak In (page does not exist)"), [Note](/index.php/Note "Note"), [Distraction](/index.php/Distraction "Distraction") |

Motion Challenge - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Motion Challenge
================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Motion Challenge** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four Accelerators. Trains your ability to transfer a technique or state from seated practice into more challenging settings, step by step. The level of challenge can be controlled by: 1. The complexity of the setting, including practice positions, types of movement, and locations (e.g., walk around your room vs. dance at a party) and 2. How challenging the technique is (e.g., Expansion/Contraction) or how deep the state is (e.g., Vibratory Flow). You can work with a motion challenge sequence to progressively increase the range of situations in which you experience a deep state, and the complexity of the situations in which you do a technique, over time. |
| **Synonyms** | [Motion Challenge Sequence (old term)](/index.php/Motion_Challenge_Sequence_(old_term) "Motion Challenge Sequence (old term)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Practice in Motion](/index.php?title=Practice_in_Motion&action=edit&redlink=1 "Practice in Motion (page does not exist)"), [Setting Options](/index.php/Setting_Options "Setting Options"), [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Situation Challenge](/index.php/Situation_Challenge "Situation Challenge"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Rewards](/index.php/Rewards "Rewards") |

Four Pillars - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Four Pillars
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Four Pillars** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Four aspects of a complete practice structure:  1. retreat practice (deeper immersion in mindfulness training, roughly a week-long retreat or equivalent amount of shorter retreats are recommended per year); 2. life practice (both formal and informal practice between retreats); 3. getting support (connecting with teachers and peers and engaging with resources for accountability and learning); and 4. giving support (informally or formally sharing practice, such as leading by example or teaching mindfulness). |
| **Synonyms** | [Four Pillars of Practice](/index.php/Four_Pillars_of_Practice "Four Pillars of Practice"), [Pillars of Practice](/index.php/Pillars_of_Practice "Pillars of Practice"), [Rhythm of Practice](/index.php/Rhythm_of_Practice "Rhythm of Practice") |

Do Nothing - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Do Nothing
==========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Do Nothing** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A technique in the Express Quadrant in which you allow attention to be spontaneously focused, rather than intentionally focusing on experience. Whenever you happen to notice that you have an intention to direct your attention, such as to follow a thought, or even toward developing CC&E, you drop that intention. Involves the most passive stance of all UM standard techniques. May result in confusion, sleepiness, or feeling like you’re not meditating, but is designed to point to Absolute Now through Auto Focus, the attainment. When CC&E is developed through this technique, that happens by naturally dropping into heightened skills due to the spontaneous focusing of attention. |
| **Synonyms** | [Auto Focus](/index.php/Auto_Focus "Auto Focus") |
| **Antonyms** |  |

Inner Visual Rest - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Inner Visual Rest
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Inner Visual Rest** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | An experience of the relative absence of activity in image space, either in a specific location or globally. Can be experienced with eyes open or closed in several ways, including:  1. detecting the absence of mental images, with eyes open or closed (You’ve developed the ability to interpret the absence of mental images as a presence of inner visual rest, like artists training to notice “negative space.”); 2. looking around or through any mental image activity in image space, with eyes open or closed. (This might be described as defocusing your “inner” gaze.); or 3. focusing on the Grayscale with eyes closed. (Even when mental images are present, the Grayscale may be soothing and help you detach from visual thought.) |
| **Synonyms** | [Restful See In](/index.php/Restful_See_In "Restful See In"), [See In Rest](/index.php/See_In_Rest "See In Rest"), [Inner See Rest](/index.php/Inner_See_Rest "Inner See Rest") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See Rest](/index.php/See_Rest "See Rest"), [See In](/index.php/See_In "See In"), [Clear Light of the Void](/index.php?title=Clear_Light_of_the_Void&action=edit&redlink=1 "Clear Light of the Void (page does not exist)"), [Grayscale](/index.php/Grayscale "Grayscale"), [Grayscale Blank](/index.php?title=Grayscale_Blank&action=edit&redlink=1 "Grayscale Blank (page does not exist)"), [Blank Mental Screen](/index.php?title=Blank_Mental_Screen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Blank Mental Screen (page does not exist)") |

Happiness Grid - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Happiness Grid
==============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Happiness Grid** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A table that organizes the pursuit of happiness into columns and rows using two basic building blocks:  1. Type: Includes five basic happiness goals, each precisely defined: Relief, Fulfillment, Insight, Mastery, Connection. 2. Level: The degree to which pursuing any given happiness goal would be obvious to the average person. Surface Level means very obvious and Deep Level means not typically obvious. For example, if you're suffering from an illness, curing the disease is the obvious form of relief you would want to pursue. But what if you can't cure it or mask the symptoms? Applying CC&E to your discomfort would be a less obvious way to pursue relief from your suffering. |
| **Synonyms** | [Periodic Table of Happiness](/index.php/Periodic_Table_of_Happiness "Periodic Table of Happiness") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Minimize Suffering](/index.php?title=Minimize_Suffering&action=edit&redlink=1 "Minimize Suffering (page does not exist)"), [Maximize Fulfillment](/index.php?title=Maximize_Fulfillment&action=edit&redlink=1 "Maximize Fulfillment (page does not exist)"), [Understand Yourself at the Deepest Level](/index.php?title=Understand_Yourself_at_the_Deepest_Level&action=edit&redlink=1 "Understand Yourself at the Deepest Level (page does not exist)"), [Act Skillfully](/index.php/Act_Skillfully "Act Skillfully"), [Get Connected](/index.php?title=Get_Connected&action=edit&redlink=1 "Get Connected (page does not exist)"), [Happiness Types](/index.php/Happiness_Types "Happiness Types") |

Formal Practice
===============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Formal Practice** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A period of practice lasting 10 minutes or more in which your attention is dedicated to a technique. Can be performed in stillness or in motion (e.g., while walking, or during an activity like gardening), with eyes open or closed, in a simple environment (e.g., in a quiet room) or a complex environment (e.g., a crowded airport). |
| **Synonyms** |  |

UMWiki:About - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


UMWiki:About
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

About the UM Wiki
-----------------

The UM Wiki is the culmination of years of working with Shinzen Young, the designer of the UM meditation system, to ensure that his teachings will be freely accessible and kept up-to-date in a centralized location available to anyone in the world.

All definitions offered in this living resource have been created in close collaboration with Shinzen and have met with his final approval. They will be updated in collaboration with him as needed.

A navigational framework will be added to the UM Wiki later this summer, which will make it easier to use it as a study aid, and an enhanced version of the UM Wiki with additional rich content will be launched later this year.

Thank you to Certified Unified Mindfulness Trainer Eric Carroll for his technical expertise in coding and Wikis and for seeing this project through to publication, to all UM Trainers and staff who have contributed, and to all of you for your passion and dedication to mindfulness practice. Whether you teach explicitly or not, the ripple effects of your practice are valuable and important beyond measure.

The team at Unified Mindfulness is honored to have been entrusted with this important work and is dedicated to continuing to support and promote the Unified Mindfulness system worldwide.

Express
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Express** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four quadrants into which ULTRA organizes training. The techniques in this quadrant invite you to develop CC&E by focusing attention on automaticity, spontaneity, or bounciness in the activity of thought, speech, body movement, and attention (i.e., Expression Modes). Trains you to ride on the forces of expansion/contraction that animate daily life, leading to enhanced creativity, aliveness, and expressiveness. |
| **Synonyms** | [Express Spontaneity](/index.php/Express_Spontaneity "Express Spontaneity"), [Express Bounce](/index.php/Express_Bounce "Express Bounce"), [Just Be Natural Family of Techniques](/index.php/Just_Be_Natural_Family_of_Techniques "Just Be Natural Family of Techniques") |

Auto Move - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Auto Move
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Auto Move** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Express Quadrant designed to develop Concentration, Clarity, and Equanimity (CC&E) by focusing attention on spontaneity in any kind of physical body movement while releasing enough control to let your body movements just happen on their own. For example, a common form of Auto Move is Auto Walk, such as while walking from Point A (say, your cubicle) to Point B (say, the bathroom). 2. Short for the act of moving with spontaneity (aka Auto, the Attainment). |
| **Synonyms** | [Feel Bounce](/index.php/Feel_Bounce "Feel Bounce"), [Move Now](/index.php/Move_Now "Move Now"), [Zen Bounce (definition 2)](/index.php/Zen_Bounce_(definition_2) "Zen Bounce (definition 2)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Center of Control](/index.php?title=Center_of_Control&action=edit&redlink=1 "Center of Control (page does not exist)"), [Auto Walk](/index.php?title=Auto_Walk&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Walk (page does not exist)"), [Express (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Express_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Express (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Spontaneity](/index.php/Spontaneity "Spontaneity"), [Auto Speak](/index.php?title=Auto_Speak&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Speak (page does not exist)"), [Guesswork](/index.php/Guesswork "Guesswork"), [Rewards](/index.php/Rewards "Rewards"), [Self CARE](/index.php/Self_CARE "Self CARE"), [Motion Challenge](/index.php/Motion_Challenge "Motion Challenge"), [Good Robot](/index.php?title=Good_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Good Robot (page does not exist)") |

Interest-Opportunity-Necessity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Interest-Opportunity-Necessity
==============================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Interest-Opportunity-Necessity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A simple way to remember your choices about what technique to practice, and which strategies, settings and technique options to use, or whether to stay with a technique. Can be applied to a specific practice session or your practice routine in general. You can make decisions based on:   1. Interest: Motivated by technique(s) you find appealing. (For example, you’re interested in exploring how SHF Out affects SHF In, so you do SHF with inclusive noting.) 2. Opportunity: Determined by the presence of Windows (Reward States, including CC&E rewards). (For example, you notice pleasant energy in the body after a run, so you do a microhit of Feel Flow.) 3. Necessity: Dictated by the needs of the moment. (For example, you can’t get yourself to practice in any other way, so you decide to practice with music for a week.)   Whatever you decide, try not to technique hop (switch from technique to technique out of drivenness or unconsciousness) and don’t make a big deal out of how you choose a technique. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Technique Hopping](/index.php?title=Technique_Hopping&action=edit&redlink=1 "Technique Hopping (page does not exist)"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options") |

Habits - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Habits
======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Habits** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. Positive routines or patterns reflected through thought, emotional well-being or skillful action. May be developed and/or deepened through systematic mindfulness training (includes mindfulness training itself). 2. Negative, subliminal blockages, unproductive mental and/or emotional routines, or unskillful behavior. May be released through purification, dropped intentionally, or improved through systematic mindfulness practice, depending on your awareness of the condition, the severity of it, and other factors (such as supplementing with psychotherapy). 3. Neutral patterns or routines. Thoughts, emotions, and/or action that have neither a clearly positive nor clearly negative effect on you or anyone else. For example, learning the names of different plants, not tending toward strong emotion, or checking your mailbox for mail each day. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Good Robot](/index.php?title=Good_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Good Robot (page does not exist)"), [Magic Robot](/index.php?title=Magic_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Magic Robot (page does not exist)"), [Neutral Robot](/index.php?title=Neutral_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Neutral Robot (page does not exist)"), [Bad Robot](/index.php?title=Bad_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bad Robot (page does not exist)"), [Evil Robot](/index.php?title=Evil_Robot&action=edit&redlink=1 "Evil Robot (page does not exist)"), [Mastery (Happiness Grid)](/index.php?title=Mastery_(Happiness_Grid)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mastery (Happiness Grid) (page does not exist)"), [Express](/index.php/Express "Express"), [Center of Control](/index.php?title=Center_of_Control&action=edit&redlink=1 "Center of Control (page does not exist)"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Vicious and Virtuous Cycles](/index.php?title=Vicious_and_Virtuous_Cycles&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vicious and Virtuous Cycles (page does not exist)") |

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Rewards
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Rewards** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Pleasant qualities and effects connected to heightened mindful awareness that may be brought on, enhanced by, or built into the skills of CC&E. Can be experienced whether you drop into heightened CC&E without training or you intentionally develop CC&E. There are five useful ways to think about it:  * CC&E may deepen fulfillment from any experience or situation that you consider pleasant, such as eating cake, watching a movie, or floating in a pool. * Pleasant states can occur as the result of heightened CC&E, such as energy (Flow), tranquility (Restful States), or emotional well-being (Feel Good). As your Baseline CC&E goes up, these commonly become more reliably present. * Each skill can have its own distinct reward qualities. For example, heightened Concentration lets you be fully absorbed in an activity, heightened Clarity can result in sensory richness or vividness, or a sense of discovery, and from heightened Equanimity there can be flow, purification, and ease of being. * Heightened baseline of CC&E offers long term rewards such as lower stress, greater spontaneity, improved well being, pleasant energy flow, etc. * From a certain perspective any reward you can possibly think of in life originates in your sensory relationship to it, which has its beginnings in CC&E. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |

Accelerators - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Accelerators
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Accelerators** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Four structured ways to speed the growth of your mindfulness skills:  * Response Challenge—intentionally taking in pleasant or unpleasant external sight, sound, or touch and systematically working with any reactions * Duration Challenge—moving less during training sessions for longer periods of time * Motion Challenge—attempting to maintain a technique during simple or complex activities * Situation Challenge—strategically practicing mindfulness techniques during life situations, which can be analyzed in terms of hedonic valence, time frame, whether you seek it out or it happens to you, etc. |
| **Synonyms** | [Practice Accelerators](/index.php/Practice_Accelerators "Practice Accelerators") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [Motion Challenge](/index.php/Motion_Challenge "Motion Challenge"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Duration Challenge](/index.php/Duration_Challenge "Duration Challenge"), [Situation Challenge](/index.php/Situation_Challenge "Situation Challenge"), [Momentum Practice](/index.php/Momentum_Practice "Momentum Practice"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits") |

Flow - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Flow
====

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Flow** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Any movement, change, energy, or force that you may perceive about a sensory experience. Includes everything from ordinary movement to special cases of Flow. Through Sensory Clarity you can detect a range of Flow in the sensory system, in terms of phases (solid to Vibratory, to Absolute), including:  1. Ordinary Flow: Any movement or change you detect in ordinary experience and/or as the result of relatively low CC&E. For instance, you see a car drive past your window, or you yawn, or you feel an itch get intense, or you hear a plane overhead moving across the sky. 2. Vibratory Flow: May have a quality of waviness, tingling, or bubbliness. Often subtle at first and only detected with heightened CC&E. Typically pleasant and can become intensely pleasant. 3. Expansion/Contraction Flow: A kind of flow which can be ordinary, vibratory, or deep phase. Includes themes such as bigger/smaller, faster/slower, and New/Gone. When CC&E reach critical mass, *Deep* Expansion/Contraction Flow may take over experience at the very surface of awareness. This is not just a kind of flow, because it’s the only form of all perception. At the Absolute level, all of space/time effortlessly expands and contracts. |
| **Synonyms** | [Fluidity](/index.php/Fluidity "Fluidity") |
| **Antonyms** | [Stability/Stable (surface only](/index.php?title=Stability/Stable_(surface_only&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stability/Stable (surface only (page does not exist)"), [See “Flow and Stability” in Finer Details)](/index.php?title=See_%E2%80%9CFlow_and_Stability%E2%80%9D_in_Finer_Details)&action=edit&redlink=1 "See “Flow and Stability” in Finer Details) (page does not exist)"), [Fixation (deep)](/index.php?title=Fixation_(deep)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fixation (deep) (page does not exist)") |
| **Related** | [General Flow](/index.php?title=General_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "General Flow (page does not exist)"), [Relative Flow](/index.php?title=Relative_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Relative Flow (page does not exist)"), [Fundamental Flow](/index.php?title=Fundamental_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fundamental Flow (page does not exist)"), [Expansion/Contraction Flow](/index.php/Expansion/Contraction_Flow "Expansion/Contraction Flow"), [See Hear Feel Now](/index.php/See_Hear_Feel_Now "See Hear Feel Now"), [Arising & Passing](/index.php?title=Arising_%26_Passing&action=edit&redlink=1 "Arising & Passing (page does not exist)"), [New/Gone](/index.php?title=New/Gone&action=edit&redlink=1 "New/Gone (page does not exist)"), [Absolute Activity](/index.php/Absolute_Activity "Absolute Activity"), [See Flow](/index.php?title=See_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "See Flow (page does not exist)"), [Hear Flow](/index.php?title=Hear_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hear Flow (page does not exist)"), [Feel Flow](/index.php/Feel_Flow "Feel Flow"), [SHF Flow](/index.php?title=SHF_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF Flow (page does not exist)"), [Transcend](/index.php/Transcend "Transcend") [(ULTRA)](/index.php?title=(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "(ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Contour](/index.php?title=Contour&action=edit&redlink=1 "Contour (page does not exist)"), [Phase](/index.php?title=Phase&action=edit&redlink=1 "Phase (page does not exist)"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls") |

Feel In - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Feel In
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Feel In** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on what you feel emotionally in the body, whether active (i.e., the presence of emotional body sensations such as anxiety in the belly) or restful (i.e., the absence of emotional body sensations, or emotional peace). (See Emotional Body Sensation) 2. Short for the space *where* you detect emotional experience in the body, for example, when guiding a practice, you might say, *Bring your attention to Feel In, the place where you usually notice emotions in your body, such as joy around your face. You might also notice the absence of emotional sensations, which would be emotional peace*. |
| **Synonyms** | [Emotional body sensation](/index.php/Emotional_body_sensation "Emotional body sensation"), [Feel In space](/index.php/Feel_In_space "Feel In space"), [Emotional body space](/index.php/Emotional_body_space "Emotional body space") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Feel](/index.php/Feel "Feel"), [Feel Out](/index.php/Feel_Out "Feel Out"), [Feel Good](/index.php/Feel_Good "Feel Good") |

Absolute - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Absolute
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Absolute** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | In Unified Mindfulness, a term for the deepest phase of experience. A synonym for terms like Oneness, Unity, Emptiness, Completeness, No Self, or True Self. Absolute describes *extraordinary* or *transcendent* experience, which contrasts with more *ordinary* or *relative* experience. Complete transcendence can’t be known directly because there is no sense of a limited *self* to know it. While putting words to it can only ever limit the limitless, the sensory system can reflect transcendence and having a name for the deepest phase of experience can be useful for communication, and increased clarity. Transcendent states can be described with more precision by using modifiers to highlight three subtle themes and their relationships: Absolute Rest, Absolute Now, and Absolute Activity. |
| **Synonyms** | [Oneness](/index.php/Oneness "Oneness"), [Emptiness](/index.php/Emptiness "Emptiness"), [Completeness](/index.php/Completeness "Completeness"), [No Self](/index.php/No_Self "No Self"), [True Self](/index.php/True_Self "True Self"), [Unity](/index.php/Unity "Unity"), [Nothingness](/index.php/Nothingness "Nothingness") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Absolute Activity](/index.php/Absolute_Activity "Absolute Activity"), [Absolute Rest](/index.php/Absolute_Rest "Absolute Rest"), [Cessation](/index.php/Cessation "Cessation"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now"), [Practice Maturity](/index.php/Practice_Maturity "Practice Maturity"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [SELF Care Integration Strategies](/index.php?title=SELF_Care_Integration_Strategies&action=edit&redlink=1 "SELF Care Integration Strategies (page does not exist)"), [Transcendence](/index.php?title=Transcendence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcendence (page does not exist)"), [Trait Mindfulness](/index.php/Trait_Mindfulness "Trait Mindfulness"), [Aspect](/index.php?title=Aspect&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aspect (page does not exist)"), [Phase](/index.php?title=Phase&action=edit&redlink=1 "Phase (page does not exist)"), [and Level](/index.php?title=And_Level&action=edit&redlink=1 "And Level (page does not exist)") |

| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on what you hear in the mind, both active (mental talk) and restful (mental quiet). 2. Integration - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Integration
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Integration** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A process that makes sure your experience of emptiness or oneness is incorporated into your humanity in a way that is fulfilling and leads to effective action. When successful, this process results in the surface mind knowing itself more completely as deep Equanimity. This helps develop a mature practice expressed through ideals such as experiential wisdom, a call to service, and the maintaining of good conduct. Primary characteristics:   1. Experientially: Emptiness/Oneness is fulfilling for the individual. 2. Objectively: Emptiness/Oneness produces effective action in the world.   When integration is successful, this mature perspective shows up through you as healthy and consistent expressions of limitless love (or your synonym of choice). |
| **Synonyms** | [Integrate](/index.php/Integrate "Integrate") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Practice Maturity](/index.php/Practice_Maturity "Practice Maturity"), [Integration Strategies (Self CARE)](/index.php?title=Integration_Strategies_(Self_CARE)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Integration Strategies (Self CARE) (page does not exist)"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight") |

Local Intensity and Wider Spread - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Local Intensity and Wider Spread
================================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Local Intensity and Wider Spread** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | When a sensory event has an effect on more distant areas of the sensory system. Sometimes called a “splash, ripple” and often used to describe sensations in the body, but can happen in any sense category or across sense categories. The level of intensity may stay the same as it spreads, but more commonly it decreases with distance from the origin point. The spread of the sensory experience and/or its influence may be detected consciously (*Conscious Spread*), or it may go undetected (*Subconscious Spread*). When you’re able to track the spread spatially and be aware of it consciously, you tend to suffer less and enhance fulfillment. **Wider Spread:**   1. The area of greatest intensity may expand somewhat but remain relatively local (for instance, an itch on your ankle expands across the whole space of your foot.) 2. 2-Way or 3-Way Spread: The area of greatest intensity spreads to and/or influences other sense categories (e.g., the itch on your ankle triggers an image of the itch in your mind).   **Global Spread:**   1. The area of greatest intensity may spread across the whole sense category (for instance, an image in your mind seems to fill all of See Space, or your hands get so big as you focus on them that they seem to take up the space of your whole body). 2. The area of greatest intensity may seem to go beyond the boundary of the sense category (for instance, silence becomes so deep, rich, and expansive that the normal sense of Hear Space goes away and the space where hearing occurs gets much bigger and more spacious). 3. The area of greatest intensity may spread to fully cover more than one sense category and/or go beyond the sense categories in some combination (for instance, the deep, rich silence develops into an extraordinary spaciousness in Hear and the felt sense of the body’s boundaries drops away. |
| **Synonyms** | [Splash/Ripple](/index.php/Splash/Ripple "Splash/Ripple") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Zooming](/index.php/Zooming "Zooming"), [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [Expansion](/index.php?title=Expansion&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expansion (page does not exist)"), [Equanimity](/index.php/Equanimity "Equanimity"), [Conscious Spread](/index.php?title=Conscious_Spread&action=edit&redlink=1 "Conscious Spread (page does not exist)"), [Subconscious Spread](/index.php?title=Subconscious_Spread&action=edit&redlink=1 "Subconscious Spread (page does not exist)"), [Window](/index.php?title=Window&action=edit&redlink=1 "Window (page does not exist)"), [Wall](/index.php?title=Wall&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wall (page does not exist)") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Local_Intensity_and_Wider_Spread&oldid=2057>"

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Relief
======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Relief** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The first column on UM’s Happiness Grid, this happiness type covers all the things people identify as causing them suffering. In doing so, it clarifies four basic forms of relief, ranging from the most obvious to the most profound:  1. You can eliminate situations you don’t want 2. You can eliminate unpleasant sensory experiences 3. You can be skillful with unpleasant sensory experiences 4. You can completely experience unpleasant sensory experiences   As with all items on the Happiness Grid, this refers both to the impact of a practice on relief and the impact of other factors, such as purposeful action, chance, and so forth. |
| **Synonyms** | [Find Relief](/index.php/Find_Relief "Find Relief") |
| **Antonyms** |  |

Gone - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Gone
====

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Gone** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. Whenever a sensory experience goes away, whether partially or completely, and you detect the instant it happens. If the experience doesn’t completely go away, you notice the moment part of it goes, whether it gets weaker (like detecting the instant a sound gets softer even if the sound doesn’t go away completely) or whether it takes up less space (like detecting the instant part of an image disappears). 2. A way to access Absolute Rest. With high enough CC&E, Gone is always available. Everything is always passing. You can direct awareness toward that at any time. You don’t need to wait for sensory experience to be a certain way. |
| **Synonyms** | [Passing](/index.php/Passing "Passing"), [Vanishing](/index.php/Vanishing "Vanishing") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Discrete Flow](/index.php?title=Discrete_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Discrete Flow (page does not exist)"), [Gone Goodies](/index.php?title=Gone_Goodies&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gone Goodies (page does not exist)"), [Just Note Gone](/index.php?title=Just_Note_Gone&action=edit&redlink=1 "Just Note Gone (page does not exist)"), [Expansion/Contraction Flow](/index.php/Expansion/Contraction_Flow "Expansion/Contraction Flow"), [New](/index.php?title=New&action=edit&redlink=1 "New (page does not exist)"), [Arising & Passing](/index.php?title=Arising_%26_Passing&action=edit&redlink=1 "Arising & Passing (page does not exist)") |

Anchor Away
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Anchor Away** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A UM focus strategy in which you actively direct attention away from a given experience and intentionally focus on another. Often used to work indirectly with unpleasant experiences that feel too challenging to approach directly, but the experience you Anchor Away from may also be pleasant. Common anchors include but are not limited to See Out, Hear Out, Feel Out, Feel Rest, or a Hear Good phrase. Pairs with Turn Toward. |
| **Synonyms** | [Turn Away (less preferable)](/index.php/Turn_Away_(less_preferable) "Turn Away (less preferable)") |
| **Antonyms** | [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward") |
| **Related** | [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [Emotional Body Sensation](/index.php/Emotional_Body_Sensation "Emotional Body Sensation"), [Background Equanimity](/index.php?title=Background_Equanimity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Background Equanimity (page does not exist)"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls") |

Analyze-Strategize-Implement-Assess - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Analyze-Strategize-Implement-Assess
===================================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Analyze-Strategize-Implement-Assess** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A four-step daily practice tool used to structure life practice in between retreats:  1. Analyze: Preview the day to come, looking for times and situations where practice could fit. 2. Strategize: Decide what techniques you'd like to apply when, and also what modes of practice you'll be using (i.e., formal or informal). 3. Implement: Act on your plan throughout your day. 4. Assess: Look back at the end of the day to reflect on successes and challenges. |
| **Synonyms** | [ASIA algorithm](/index.php/ASIA_algorithm "ASIA algorithm") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [Technique](/index.php/Technique "Technique"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options"), [Modes of Practice](/index.php?title=Modes_of_Practice&action=edit&redlink=1 "Modes of Practice (page does not exist)"), [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [ION](/index.php/ION "ION") |

Noting - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Noting
======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Noting** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A widely used approach for developing CC&E that involves acknowledging and focusing on sensory experience for brief moments of time which can last anywhere from a fraction of a second to thirty seconds or more (using what is known as momentary concentration). Labeling is an option to support the process. Each individual act of noting involves two parts:   1. Acknowledge a sensory experience, which takes only a fraction of a second. 2. The second part depends on what happens next.     1. If the experience instantly vanishes, simply be aware that it has vanished.    2. If the experience does not immediately vanish, then briefly focus on it (you can actively give the experience your attention or passively receive it). This “focus on” phase may last from a fraction of a second to many seconds depending on your personal style or the needs of the moment. |
| **Synonyms** | [Note](/index.php/Note "Note") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Momentary Concentration](/index.php?title=Momentary_Concentration&action=edit&redlink=1 "Momentary Concentration (page does not exist)"), [Focus On Phase](/index.php?title=Focus_On_Phase&action=edit&redlink=1 "Focus On Phase (page does not exist)"), [Gone](/index.php/Gone "Gone") |

Sense Category
==============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Sense Category** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The broadest grouping into which sensory perception—as opposed to expression—is sorted in UM. The categories are See (visual experience), Hear (auditory experience), and Feel (body experience, including taste and smell, as well as emotional body sensations). |
| **Synonyms** | [Sensory Category](/index.php/Sensory_Category "Sensory Category"), [Modality (category is preferred)](/index.php/Modality_(category_is_preferred) "Modality (category is preferred)"), [Sensory Modality](/index.php/Sensory_Modality "Sensory Modality"), [Channel](/index.php/Channel "Channel"), [Mode](/index.php/Mode "Mode"), [Space](/index.php/Space "Space"), [Sense Gate](/index.php/Sense_Gate "Sense Gate") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See](/index.php/See "See"), [Hear](/index.php/Hear "Hear"), [Feel](/index.php/Feel "Feel"), [See space](/index.php/See_space "See space"), [Hear space](/index.php/Hear_space "Hear space"), [Feel space](/index.php/Feel_space "Feel space"), [Spatiality](/index.php?title=Spatiality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Spatiality (page does not exist)"), [Perception/Expression](/index.php?title=Perception/Expression&action=edit&redlink=1 "Perception/Expression (page does not exist)"), [Expression Mode](/index.php?title=Expression_Mode&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expression Mode (page does not exist)"), [In/Out](/index.php/In/Out "In/Out") |

Spaciousness
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Spaciousness** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A reward state, which is the focus range of the SHF Space technique family (See Space, Hear Space, Feel Space, SHF Space) in the Transcend Quadrant of ULTRA. Often described as the openness around and thinness within experience. Openness loosely maps to expansion and thinness to contraction. You may detect one more easily than the other. Higher CC&E means Purification reveals less substance and more nothingness in an experience, or sense category. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** | [Denseness](/index.php?title=Denseness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Denseness (page does not exist)") |

Main Page
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

Welcome to the Unified Mindfulness Wiki
---------------------------------------

The UM Wiki serves as a resource for the most up-to-date definitions, terms, techniques, and formulation of the Unified Mindfulness meditation system.
  


* [Category:Definitions](/index.php/Category:Definitions "Category:Definitions")
* [Category:Terms of Service](/index.php/Category:Terms_of_Service "Category:Terms of Service")

About the UM Wiki
-----------------

The UM Wiki is the culmination of years of working with Shinzen Young, the designer of the UM meditation system, to ensure that his teachings will be freely accessible and kept up-to-date in a centralized location available to anyone in the world.

All definitions offered in this living resource have been created in close collaboration with Shinzen and have met with his final approval. They will be updated in collaboration with him as needed.

A navigational framework will be added to the UM Wiki later this summer, which will make it easier to use it as a study aid, and an enhanced version of the UM Wiki with additional rich content will be launched later this year.

Thank you to Certified Unified Mindfulness Trainer Eric Carroll for his technical expertise in coding and Wikis and for seeing this project through to publication, to all UM Trainers and staff who have contributed, and to all of you for your passion and dedication to mindfulness practice. Whether you teach explicitly or not, the ripple effects of your practice are valuable and important beyond measure.

The team at Unified Mindfulness is honored to have been entrusted with this important work and is dedicated to continuing to support and promote the Unified Mindfulness system worldwide.

Nurture Positive - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Nurture Positive
================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Nurture Positive** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four quadrants into which ULTRA classifies training. The techniques in this quadrant invite you to develop CC&E by intentionally encouraging positivity in inner SHF experience. NP techniques use sustained concentration. These are not Noting techniques. You stay focused on a positive experience you’ve accessed or generated until that experience is gone. Then you repeat the process.  To motivate positivity, *Follow your Heart BEATS.* This wordplay helps you remember basic content options.  **Heart BEATS:**  **B**: Behavior. You can improve how you act, such as drinking more water.  **E**: Emotions. You can improve how you feel, such as experiencing more gratitude.  **A**: Aspiration. You can improve who you are, such as becoming more like a role model you admire.  **T:** Thought. You can improve how you think, such as the ability to interpret data using logic and evidence.  **S**: Situations. You can improve situations, such as preparing for an upcoming interview.  You can also mix categories. For instance, strengthening the belief that you are lovable involves both Emotions and Thought. |
| **Synonyms** | [Improve](/index.php/Improve "Improve") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Loving Kindness](/index.php?title=Loving_Kindness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Loving Kindness (page does not exist)"), [Metta Practice](/index.php?title=Metta_Practice&action=edit&redlink=1 "Metta Practice (page does not exist)"), [See Good](/index.php/See_Good "See Good"), [Hear Good](/index.php?title=Hear_Good&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hear Good (page does not exist)"), [Feel Good](/index.php/Feel_Good "Feel Good"), [Be Good](/index.php/Be_Good "Be Good"), [Virtuous Cycle](/index.php?title=Virtuous_Cycle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Virtuous Cycle (page does not exist)"), [Self CARE](/index.php/Self_CARE "Self CARE"), [Equanimity](/index.php/Equanimity "Equanimity"), [ULTRA](/index.php/ULTRA "ULTRA"), [Appreciate (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Appreciate_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Appreciate (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Transcend (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Transcend_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcend (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Express (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Express_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Express (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits") |
