Aspect-Phase-Level - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Aspect-Phase-Level
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Aspect-Phase-Level** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Three connected ways to organize sensory experience and your relationship to it so you can work with and integrate it more effectively. As your CC&E *level* heightens, the *phase* of your experience deepens, and you detect the *aspects* less as content (solid and separate) and more as contour (flowing and unified). **Aspect:** The groups or subgroup into which you can organize the content of your experience. To help you appreciate experience (by untangling and unblocking it), UM organizes your sensory experience into 12 basic groups: The three sense categories (See, Hear, Feel, or SHF) each have four main groups—Inner, Outer, Active, and Restful. The three main categories divided into four subgroups make 12 Aspects, which cover all possibilities. Any experience you have is some combination of these 12 aspects. The main Aspects may be combined and/or broken into smaller groups (Sub Aspects). An example of a combination is seeing a bird and hearing it chirp while feeling joyful (See Out, Hear Out, Feel In). An example of a sub aspect is the specific sound of the chirp and location of the bird. You can also relate to the contour of deeper phases of your experience as content in order to further unblock and untangle it. For example, tingling vibratory flow in your heart area can be worked with as content and understood in terms of its aspects (General Aspects: Active Feel Out. Sub Aspect of Feel Out: Flow, Heart Area. Sub Aspect of Flow: Vibratory Flow. Sub Aspect of Vibratory Flow: Tingling, Pleasant Hedonic Valence, etc.)  **Phase:** The degree of transcendence in sensory perception and expression. Commonly, how much your sensory experience is flowing, spacious, and/or spontaneous. UM themes of In, Out, Rest, Flow, Space, Now, Bounce, Good, and All Themes—can be explored and/or experienced at any phase, from ordinary, or surface phase, to extraordinary, or deep phase. Knowing about this continuum helps you become sensitized to and integrate transcendence. Other terms for the deepest phase of experience include the Absolute, Non-Duality, No Self, Expansion/Contraction Flow, Oneness, and effortless Goodness, or Love.  **Level:** Your degree of Concentration, Clarity, and Equanimity (CC&E). The lower your level of CC&E, the more you may need to untangle and unblock aspects of experience. You are more aware of content. The higher your level of CC&E the more your surface mind is in contact with deeper phases of experience. You are more aware of contour. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Deconstruct](/index.php/Deconstruct "Deconstruct"), [Quality](/index.php?title=Quality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Quality (page does not exist)"), [CC&E](/index.php/CC%26E "CC&E"), [Sensory Experience](/index.php/Sensory_Experience "Sensory Experience"), [Sense Category](/index.php/Sense_Category "Sense Category"), [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [In/Out](/index.php/In/Out "In/Out"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow"), [Spaciousness](/index.php/Spaciousness "Spaciousness"), [Expansion/Contraction](/index.php?title=Expansion/Contraction&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expansion/Contraction (page does not exist)"), [Source](/index.php/Source "Source"), [Spontaneity](/index.php/Spontaneity "Spontaneity"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Practice](/index.php?title=Practice&action=edit&redlink=1 "Practice (page does not exist)") [Maturity](/index.php?title=Maturity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Maturity (page does not exist)"), [Absolute](/index.php/Absolute "Absolute"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now"), [Absolute Rest](/index.php/Absolute_Rest "Absolute Rest") |

Momentary and Sustained Concentration Types - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Momentary and Sustained Concentration Types
===========================================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Momentary and Sustained Concentration Types** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. Two complementary and contrasting ways to strengthen your ability to focus on what you choose. Different techniques emphasize each type. Since both types share the purpose of concentration skill development, with heightened CC&E the distinction between them may become less important.   **Sustained Focus (or Concentration):** Trying to maintain focus on something, whether small or large, for as long as you can, or as long as the object of focus lasts. Typically used in the two UM contact strategies of Even Coverage (holding attention in a set location for as long as you can, such as in Feel Good or a special exercise like following the breath) and Systematic Inventory (maintaining steady contact across the extent of a space, such as in body sweeping). May also be used in Free Float, for instance, you could stay with the sound of a plane flying by for as long as it lasts. (Note ’til Gone is an example of Sustained Concentration.)  **Momentary Focus (or Concentration):** Focusing your attention on anything, whether small or large, for anywhere from a split second to 30 seconds or longer, depending on things like your natural patterns and what you’re focusing on. You can have an experience of deeply focused attention that may also be quite brief. Commonly associated with the UM contact strategy of Free Float, builds concentration through repetitions and is the basis of Noting (such as in See Hear Feel). May also be used in Systematic Inventory (for instance, a special exercise like noting body locations).   2. A way to describe different lengths of focus as they appear in life when you’re not intentionally developing concentration. For instance, rapid and precise shifts in focus, common in the martial arts, can be thought of as momentary. Being absorbed in an activity over an extended length of time can be thought of as sustained. |
| **Synonyms** | [Sustained Focus and Momentary Focus](/index.php/Sustained_Focus_and_Momentary_Focus "Sustained Focus and Momentary Focus") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Concentration](/index.php/Concentration "Concentration"), [Noting](/index.php/Noting "Noting"), [Re-Noting](/index.php?title=Re-Noting&action=edit&redlink=1 "Re-Noting (page does not exist)"), [Contact Strategy](/index.php?title=Contact_Strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Contact Strategy (page does not exist)") |

Mastery - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Mastery
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Mastery** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The fourth column on UM’s Happiness Grid, this happiness type refers to skillful action and behavior (i.e., actions or behaviors that are considered positive, good, beneficial, adaptive, etc.). As with all items on the Happiness Grid, this refers both to the impact of a practice and the impact of other factors such as learning activities, behavioral support, chance, and so forth. From the viewpoint of practice, you can use mindfulness skills and techniques to help you:  1. Attain fun performance skills (e.g., improve your tennis game) 2. Attain skills to help you succeed in life (e.g., improve your public speaking for your job) 3. Make necessary behavior changes (e.g., eat differently) and/or follow your core values (e.g., developing character skills by using your words more carefully) 4. Attain spontaneity (e.g., move, speak, and think with effortless grace) |
| **Synonyms** | [Act Skillfully](/index.php/Act_Skillfully "Act Skillfully") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Relief](/index.php/Relief "Relief"), [Fulfillment](/index.php/Fulfillment "Fulfillment"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Connection](/index.php/Connection "Connection"), [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Happiness Types](/index.php/Happiness_Types "Happiness Types"), [Spontaneity](/index.php/Spontaneity "Spontaneity"), [Perception/Expression](/index.php?title=Perception/Expression&action=edit&redlink=1 "Perception/Expression (page does not exist)") |

Duration Challenge
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Duration Challenge** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four accelerators which trains your ability to do a session of formal practice in stillness with less movement over longer periods of time. There are two ways your range of rigor can be controlled: the length of the practice session and how much you adjust your position (e.g., attempting to move less than usual or holding a set position without any movement at all). |
| **Synonyms** | [Duration training (old term)](/index.php/Duration_training_(old_term) "Duration training (old term)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Strong Determination Sit](/index.php?title=Strong_Determination_Sit&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strong Determination Sit (page does not exist)"), [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Motion Challenge](/index.php/Motion_Challenge "Motion Challenge"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Situation Challenge](/index.php/Situation_Challenge "Situation Challenge") |

See Hear Feel Now - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


See Hear Feel Now
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See Hear Feel Now** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A technique in the Transcend Quadrant that focuses attention on Expansion/Contraction Flow and its disappearance. Designed to point to the Absolute. Includes all deep phase themes that may come up. As a reminder here are relevant *Absolute Now* themes:   1. The perception of any form as formless (Absolute Activity or Deep E/C Flow) 2. The perception of time as formless (*Def 2)* 3. The perception of formlessness (Absolute Rest as cessation) 4. Deep Spontaneity in Expression *(Def 6)*   When you’re in a deeper phase of experience contacting Vibratory Flow and/or Spaciousness, deep Expansion/Contraction Flow may naturally show up as a unifying theme and if so, you can systematically explore and work with that theme. Can also be used as a sensitizing exercise to explore Expansion/Contraction in more surface ways, such as focusing on any increase and/or decrease in intensity, frequency, and/or size of a sensory experience, any outward and/or inward pressure, or any scattering and/or gathering force. This includes how that may happen in Vibratory Flow. Also includes the resolving of these aspects into Rest. |
| **Synonyms** | [Be Now](/index.php/Be_Now "Be Now") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [ULTRA](/index.php/ULTRA "ULTRA"), [Transcend](/index.php/Transcend "Transcend"), [See Now](/index.php?title=See_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "See Now (page does not exist)"), [Hear Now](/index.php?title=Hear_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hear Now (page does not exist)"), [Feel Now](/index.php?title=Feel_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "Feel Now (page does not exist)"), [Absolute](/index.php/Absolute "Absolute"), [Absolute Activity](/index.php/Absolute_Activity "Absolute Activity"), [Absolute Rest](/index.php/Absolute_Rest "Absolute Rest"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now"), [Spontaneity](/index.php/Spontaneity "Spontaneity"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow"), [Spaciousness](/index.php/Spaciousness "Spaciousness"), [Aspect-Phase-Level](/index.php/Aspect-Phase-Level "Aspect-Phase-Level"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Guesswork](/index.php/Guesswork "Guesswork"), [New/Gone](/index.php?title=New/Gone&action=edit&redlink=1 "New/Gone (page does not exist)"), [Discrete](/index.php?title=Discrete&action=edit&redlink=1 "Discrete (page does not exist)") [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow"), [Vibratory Flow](/index.php?title=Vibratory_Flow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vibratory Flow (page does not exist)"), [Scattered (vs. having a central axis of focus)](/index.php?title=Scattered_(vs._having_a_central_axis_of_focus)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Scattered (vs. having a central axis of focus) (page does not exist)"), [Fixated/Un-fixated](/index.php?title=Fixated/Un-fixated&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fixated/Un-fixated (page does not exist)") |

Background Practice - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Background Practice
===================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Background Practice** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A type of informal practice described in UM. Compared to formal practice or microhits, a smaller portion of your attention is dedicated to doing the technique and you’re not keeping track of how long you’re practicing. While mostly focusing on whatever activity you’re doing, you typically devote 10% to 20% of your attention to applying mindfulness skills, though more or less is possible. Some techniques that are easy to use for this kind of informal practice may include Feel Rest, Just Feel, Feel Good, and others. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Informal Practice](/index.php/Informal_Practice "Informal Practice"), [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [Microhit](/index.php/Microhit "Microhit"), [Momentum Practice](/index.php/Momentum_Practice "Momentum Practice"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA") |

Practice Maturity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Practice Maturity
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Practice Maturity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The ideal direction for mindfulness training to move in over time. Lifelong self-transcendence and improvement through mindfulness may often be subtle, on a continuum, and/or evolve over decades. Behavioral and ethical points are nonnegotiable. The main ways we think about it in UM are in terms of four relationship: to mindfulness training, pleasure and pain, interpersonally, and with transcendence:  **Maturity (Training)**   * You have a commitment to maintaining the pillars and accelerators. * You take the approach that you’re never done with this process.   **Maturity (Pleasure/Pain)**   * You view all sensory experience, pleasant and unpleasant, as valuable. For example…   + Preferences bother you less because purification is fulfilling with both pleasant and unpleasant sensory experiences.   + You don’t equate pleasant effects with progress and unpleasant effects with a lack of progress—either can be a sign of progress.   **Maturity (Interpersonal)**   * You maintain ethical conduct by the broad norms of humanity and by your personal values. Depending on their role in your life, these may also be coupled with guidelines set out by UM and other professions, your community, religious group, and/or family and friends. * You keep your feedback channels open and you are accountable for behavior that causes harm even if it was not your intent * You love being around anyone, regardless of that person's current level of maturity. Equally able to be fulfilled in the presence of those who are suffering/negative as when around those who are not.   **Maturity (Transcendence)**   * You effectively integrate deep insight. You have access to Now, on demand, as you go about daily life. That keeps deepening. (Reference: Absolute Now). * You understand and manifest the complementarity between Transcend the world and go beyond yourself; benefit the world and refine yourself. (this is the highest level of maturity with transcendence). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Feedback](/index.php?title=Feedback&action=edit&redlink=1 "Feedback (page does not exist)"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Mastery](/index.php/Mastery "Mastery"), [Ethical Guidelines](/index.php?title=Ethical_Guidelines&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ethical Guidelines (page does not exist)"), [Four Pillars](/index.php/Four_Pillars "Four Pillars"), [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now") |

See Hear Feel Out
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)

| **Term** | **See Hear Feel Out** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on activity and rest in See Out, Hear Out, and Feel Out. Sometimes called Focus Out. 2. Shorthand for sensory experience in the outer spaces, which includes:  * See Out (physical sights and the restful soft gaze) * Hear Out (physical sounds and silence) * Feel Out (physical type body sensations—as opposed to emotional—including taste and smell, and physical rest, including relaxation and the absence of body sensations) |

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Universal Library for Training Attention** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A classification grid that organizes and unifies meditation practices from around the world and across the ages. Designed to give an intuitive, balanced, and comprehensive overview of meditative practice and experience. Techniques are organized based on how they highlight and explore different aspects, phases, and themes of experience. Taken together, the four quadrants—Appreciate, Transcend, Express, Nurture—form a complete picture of practice. 2. Also, a set of 40 Standard Unified Mindfulness techniques inspired by the classification grid.   **The ULTRA Grid:** |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Appreciate (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Appreciate_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Appreciate (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Transcend (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Transcend_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcend (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Nurture Positive (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Nurture_Positive_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nurture Positive (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Express (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Express_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Express (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Standard Technique](/index.php/Standard_Technique "Standard Technique"), [Theme](/index.php?title=Theme&action=edit&redlink=1 "Theme (page does not exist)"), [Special Exercise](/index.php/Special_Exercise "Special Exercise") |

See Hear Feel Good
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See Hear Feel Good** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A technique in the Nurture Positive Quadrant that focuses attention on positive mental imagery, positive mental talk, and positive body emotions. The deeper intent is to transcend the limited identity and know yourself as limitless love by way of filling up the inner system with positivity until it’s uncontained and separateness drops away. |
| **Synonyms** | [Be Good](/index.php/Be_Good "Be Good") |
| **Antonyms** |  |

Absolute Rest - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Absolute Rest
=============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Absolute Rest** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Five closely related ways of saying the same thing from a different perspective:  1. **A Temporary State: Formlessness Beyond Space/Time.** What registers in sensory perception is the absence of all form, including your own, and without even light. You're not asleep and there’s clear awareness of no space/time, self/world, at all. Compared to relative experience (from active to restful), the difference is that conscious awareness is in full contact with complete nothingness. If you experience only light or only gray without form, that’s on the scale toward Absolute Rest but is still considered the restful side of Absolute Activity. The deepest end of the scale is void of even those hints of form in sensory perception. What we call Absolute Rest is the senses reflecting consciousness without form—at the edge of the total disappearance of the self. There is at once a sense of total nothingness and also total potential—Nothingness contains all possibilities, unmanifested. When the self fully disappears from sensory perception there is no self to perceive the disappearance. During the temporary transcendent state of Absolute Rest, this disappearance of form could last a split second or longer. What matters is that whether entering into or coming out of nothingness, the complete disappearance cuts across all experience and clearly registers at the surface of awareness. 2. **A Temporary State: Formlessness as Form.** The formless rest in and beyond transcendent sensory perception and motor expression (i.e., the deep phase spontaneity, expansion/contraction flow, and timelessness of Absolute Now). Absolute Rest is not separate from Absolute Now although the two may seem to alternate. In the hierarchy of UM’s terms for the Absolute, Absolute Rest is the main term. The term Absolute Now is nested under Absolute Rest. The term Absolute Activity is nested under Absolute Now. Deep Spontaneity and Deep Expansion/Contraction Flow are themes in Absolute Now. But, whatever you call it, and from whatever angle you approach it, there is only one Absolute. Absolute Rest is not separate. Absolute Rest can be thought of as the origin of Absolute Now because it points to the highest degree of formlessness. Absolute Rest can be thought of *as* Absolute Now because there is no spectrum of Absoluteness. It’s all One. 3. **A Basic Sensory Trait.** Sensory Non-separateness, whether you’re aware of it or not. Even if you aren’t experiencing it consciously, sensory non-separateness is the origin of and even the substance (i.e., non-substance) of all sensory experience, whether more ordinary or extraordinary. The discovery of Absolute Rest is part of human potential because it is nothing more than sensory perception and expression experienced with a high degree of CC&E. The nature of sensory perception and expression doesn’t change. Your ability to recognize what has always been changes. So, whether you personally are aware of it or not, the ability to contact Absolute Rest is a sensory possibility for human beings, generally. It’s always there, waiting to be revealed. The ordinary is the Absolute. 4. **A Deepening Attainment.** The nothingness known more consistently through deepening CC&E. Your conscious awareness of and access to Absolute Rest, based on the degree and consistency of your clear experience with Absolute Rest, generally as a result of training. Whether an experienced meditator is intentionally in contact with Absolute Rest or not, Absolute Rest is more consistently and profoundly informing an advanced meditator’s everyday experience. And, due to momentum practice, an advanced meditator is more in contact with Absolute Rest, overall, as compared with someone who does not meditate. So the degree and consistency of Absolute Rest is greater. In other words, there is a deepening spiral of Absolute Rest in conscious awareness sometimes talked about as more zeros or deeper zeros. The deepening and broadening of your access to nothingness means that nothingness is more richly and completely known. Yesterday's nothingness is viewed as today’s deepening experience because today's clear depth of nothingness was not accessible yesterday. Your learning from contact with Absolute Rest never stops and most importantly, it positively affects how you manifest in the world—how fulfilling your life is, how fully you love, and how effectively you act. 5. **A Focus Range.** The Focus Range of Turn Back, for example. Direct Pointing (Point) techniques may take as their Focus Range the origin of and insubstantiality of sensory experience. You can’t purposely hold your attention on Absolute Rest. Absolute Rest holds you—whether as complete formlessness, or as Absolute Now. And the perception, *I’m directing my attention toward Nothingness,* is itself made of Nothingness. So is the impression of a thing called attention, or skills called CC&E, or the Self who is doing anything, for that matter. But, a technique may still call Absolute Rest the Focus Range of the technique, whether you’re able to clearly access it or not (i.e., whether you clearly know yourself as Nothingness/Non-separateness or not). A technique may still say: *Absolute Rest is what you’re meant to find,* as the description of the range of what you’re focusing on. |
| **Synonyms** | [Source](/index.php/Source "Source"), [Cessation](/index.php/Cessation "Cessation") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Absolute](/index.php/Absolute "Absolute"), [Absolute Activity](/index.php/Absolute_Activity "Absolute Activity"), [Absolute Now](/index.php/Absolute_Now "Absolute Now"), [Relative Rest](/index.php?title=Relative_Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Relative Rest (page does not exist)"), [Transcendence](/index.php?title=Transcendence&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcendence (page does not exist)"), [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [Aspect](/index.php?title=Aspect&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aspect (page does not exist)"), [Phase](/index.php?title=Phase&action=edit&redlink=1 "Phase (page does not exist)"), [Level](/index.php?title=Level&action=edit&redlink=1 "Level (page does not exist)"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Zero](/index.php?title=Zero&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zero (page does not exist)"), [Emptiness](/index.php/Emptiness "Emptiness"), [Loving to Death/Complete Experience](/index.php?title=Loving_to_Death/Complete_Experience&action=edit&redlink=1 "Loving to Death/Complete Experience (page does not exist)") |

Free Float - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Free Float
==========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Free Float** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of three basic contact strategies (Free Float, Systematic Inventory, and Even Coverage). In techniques with this contact strategy, attention is allowed to move from place to place, free to focus on whatever experiences are included in the focus range of the technique. The experiences attended to could be restricted (e.g., only restful body sensations, as in Feel Rest) or unrestricted (as in SHF). This contact strategy is commonly used in many Unified Mindfulness techniques. |
| **Synonyms** | [Broad Float](/index.php/Broad_Float "Broad Float") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Contact Strategy](/index.php?title=Contact_Strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Contact Strategy (page does not exist)"), [Even Coverage](/index.php?title=Even_Coverage&action=edit&redlink=1 "Even Coverage (page does not exist)"), [Systematic Inventory](/index.php?title=Systematic_Inventory&action=edit&redlink=1 "Systematic Inventory (page does not exist)"), [Stance](/index.php?title=Stance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stance (page does not exist)"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options") |

Trait Mindfulness - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Trait Mindfulness
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Trait Mindfulness** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A UM-specific way to understand consistent, positive features of your experience and behavior that are a result of your mindfulness training. The main ones identified are:  * Heightened Baseline CC&E on average in daily life when you’re not particularly trying to be that way * Reward states, for instance, vibratory flow reliably accessible in daily life and even when you have a sensory challenge * The ability to apply mindfulness strategies well * Skillful behavior due to elevated CC&E * The ability to communicate clearly about mindfulness |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Baseline CC&E](/index.php?title=Baseline_CC%26E&action=edit&redlink=1 "Baseline CC&E (page does not exist)"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits"), [Momentum Practice](/index.php/Momentum_Practice "Momentum Practice"), [Rewards](/index.php/Rewards "Rewards"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Mastery (Happiness Grid)](/index.php?title=Mastery_(Happiness_Grid)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mastery (Happiness Grid) (page does not exist)"), [Connection (Happiness Grid)](/index.php?title=Connection_(Happiness_Grid)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Connection (Happiness Grid) (page does not exist)"), [Four Pillars (of Practice)](/index.php?title=Four_Pillars_(of_Practice)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Four Pillars (of Practice) (page does not exist)") |

Robots - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Robots
======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Robots** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | UM identifies a range of automatic habits of expression, playfully called robots because you don’t control them. You are not the robot, or the robot’s behavior, whether you’re acting out of unconsciousness or out of the insight that there is no self controlling anything. The spectrum includes: Evil, Bad, Neutral, Good, and Magic. **Evil Robot:** Acting from Auto without concern for ethical or skillful behavior. Inappropriate use of mindfulness practice in general and Auto in specific. Has a very special meaning, which is the general idea that, *As long as I'm loving and empty (i.e., acting from a place of Auto/Spontaneity), I can treat people badly and get away with anything*. Creating feedback channels for your own behavior can help you avoid this trap.  **Bad Robot:** Unskillful actions, whether ethical or behavioral, which happen automatically or out of habit and without awareness. For example, verbally snapping at others when irritated, compulsively checking online notifications, or eating unhealthy foods when upset. Happens in daily life for people with or without practice—for instance, they see themselves doing things they regret, but keep doing it.  **Neutral Robot:** Ordinary actions in daily life performed without any awareness, on *autopilot*. For example, holding a conversation while walking (who is walking?) or being lost in thought and arriving at a location when you drive (who drove?). These routine actions could be neutral, such as checking the mail, or positive, such as eating a healthy snack.  **Good Robot:** Intentionally developing CC&E by focusing on Auto. Nurturing an awareness of just happening or spontaneity of expression (Think, Speak, Move), which you systematically explore and enjoy with CC&E, to meet any happiness goal.  **Magic Robot:** Speech, thought, and/or body expression that is both admirable in content and effortless in contour. In other words, the content is highly appropriate and beneficial, given the situation, and expressed with conscious spontaneity or bounce. Combines the sense of being completely free with the sense of being largely controlled by positive habits. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits"), [Zen Sickness](/index.php?title=Zen_Sickness&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zen Sickness (page does not exist)"), [Crazy Wisdom](/index.php?title=Crazy_Wisdom&action=edit&redlink=1 "Crazy Wisdom (page does not exist)"), [Express (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Express_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Express (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Auto Think](/index.php?title=Auto_Think&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Think (page does not exist)"), [Auto Speak](/index.php?title=Auto_Speak&action=edit&redlink=1 "Auto Speak (page does not exist)"), [Auto Move](/index.php/Auto_Move "Auto Move"), [Feedback](/index.php?title=Feedback&action=edit&redlink=1 "Feedback (page does not exist)") |

Purification - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Purification
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Purification** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The main reward associated with Equanimity. Over time, CC&E act on your sensory system to remove or release to the surface whatever gets in the way of deep Equanimity. We can use the word purification to talk about these aspects of practice experience:  1. Having equanimity when blockages (holdings that create sensory friction) are removed at the deep level through momentum practice 2. Having equanimity when stored blockages come to the surface to get released through intentional practice (for instance, through deconstructing them) 3. Recognizing how the process of release helps you access deeper CC&E more consistently 4. Developing an appreciation for this process so it gives you a kind of fulfillment |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Rhythm of Release](/index.php?title=Rhythm_of_Release&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rhythm of Release (page does not exist)"), [Taste of Purification](/index.php?title=Taste_of_Purification&action=edit&redlink=1 "Taste of Purification (page does not exist)"), [Equanimity](/index.php/Equanimity "Equanimity"), [CC&E Rewards](/index.php?title=CC%26E_Rewards&action=edit&redlink=1 "CC&E Rewards (page does not exist)"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Complete Experience](/index.php?title=Complete_Experience&action=edit&redlink=1 "Complete Experience (page does not exist)"), [Strange Experience(s)](/index.php?title=Strange_Experience(s)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strange Experience(s) (page does not exist)") |

Strategy - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Strategy
========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Strategy** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A practice approach you apply to a particular sensory experience, either during practice (e.g., you’re doing See Hear Feel and suddenly there’s a lot of Flow in the body) or related to an objective situation (e.g., a co-worker speaks unkindly to you and you need to manage your reactions). Strategies can involve selecting a technique, technique options (like spoken labels), and/or setting options (i.e., formal/informal), and you can use them to address specific windows or walls, or ordinary experiences and situations. Common strategy options include:   1. Turn Toward 2. Anchor Away 3. Some combination of the two |
| **Synonyms** | [Practice Strategy](/index.php/Practice_Strategy "Practice Strategy"), [Focus Strategy](/index.php/Focus_Strategy "Focus Strategy") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA"), [Technique](/index.php/Technique "Technique"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options") |

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Setting Options
===============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Setting Options** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | In UM, the degree of formality and motion you can choose for implementing a technique. The two parts are:  1. Formality: The amount of intention and time you put into your practice, from formal to informal. 2. Motion: The spectrum of practice positions, states, and locations. Ranges from more withdrawn (including practice in dreamless sleep, awake but lying down, or seated with eyes closed) to more engaged with the world around you (seated with eyes open, moving slowly, or in a more active environment such as moving around normally or during life activities out in the world). |
| **Synonyms** | [Modes of Practice (old term)](/index.php/Modes_of_Practice_(old_term) "Modes of Practice (old term)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Formal Practice](/index.php/Formal_Practice "Formal Practice"), [Informal Practice](/index.php/Informal_Practice "Informal Practice"), [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA"), [Background Practice](/index.php/Background_Practice "Background Practice"), [Microhit](/index.php/Microhit "Microhit"), [Motion Challenge](/index.php/Motion_Challenge "Motion Challenge"), [Duration Challenge](/index.php/Duration_Challenge "Duration Challenge"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options") |

Focus Range & Instruction Set - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Focus Range & Instruction Set
=============================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Focus Range & Instruction Set** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | **Focus Range:** The sensory experience or set of experiences that you focus on, spontaneously drop into, or return attention to, depending on the technique. Can be organized by space, time, quality, and most commonly, some combination of those (called *Scope*). The scope of UM Standard Techniques is mostly organized by quality (aspects and sub-aspects of See Hear Feel). The scope of Special Exercises may also be more spatial, such as the narrow scope of the breath *at the tip of the nose*, or time oriented, such as the brief scope of Just Note Gone—the *instant* of disappearance. Contrasts with Distraction Set/Space. **Instruction Set:** The directions you follow (often from memory) to practice a technique. A robust technique includes ways you can develop CC&E, whether clearly explained (e.g., *you develop Equanimity by creating relaxation in the body*) or more indirect (e.g., *you’re making friends with your emotions*). Some parts of an Instruction Set include things like Contact Strategy, Content Strategy, Focus Style, Concentration Type, and Technique Options. |
| **Synonyms** | [Focus Space](/index.php/Focus_Space "Focus Space"), [Range & Rules](/index.php/Range_%26_Rules "Range & Rules") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Technique](/index.php/Technique "Technique"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options"), [Quality](/index.php?title=Quality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Quality (page does not exist)"), [Aspect-Phase-Level](/index.php/Aspect-Phase-Level "Aspect-Phase-Level"), [Spatiality/Space](/index.php/Spatiality/Space "Spatiality/Space"), [Momentary & Sustained Concentration Types](/index.php?title=Momentary_%26_Sustained_Concentration_Types&action=edit&redlink=1 "Momentary & Sustained Concentration Types (page does not exist)"), [Contact Strategy](/index.php?title=Contact_Strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Contact Strategy (page does not exist)"), [Content Strategy](/index.php?title=Content_Strategy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Content Strategy (page does not exist)"), [Noting](/index.php/Noting "Noting"), [Labeling](/index.php/Labeling "Labeling"), [Stance](/index.php?title=Stance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stance (page does not exist)"), [Emphasis](/index.php?title=Emphasis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Emphasis (page does not exist)"), [Zooming](/index.php/Zooming "Zooming"), [Distraction](/index.php/Distraction "Distraction"), [ION](/index.php/ION "ION"), [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away") |

UMWiki:Privacy policy - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


UMWiki:Privacy policy
=====================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

At Unified Mindfulness LLC (“Company” or “we”), we endeavor to protect your privacy, as we know how important it is for you. In brief, this Privacy Policy is to ensure you that we will never sell, rent, trade, or abuse your information. For more specific concerns, please take the time to read the rest of the Privacy Policy below where you can see how we collect, communicate, disclose, and use your personal information.

Contents
--------

* [1 Privacy Policy – What information do we collect from you?](#Privacy_Policy_–_What_information_do_we_collect_from_you?)
* [2 What do we use your information for?](#What_do_we_use_your_information_for?)
* [3 Do We Use Cookies?](#Do_We_Use_Cookies?)
* [4 How do we protect your information?](#How_do_we_protect_your_information?)
* [5 Do we disclose any information to outside parties?](#Do_we_disclose_any_information_to_outside_parties?)
* [6 Affiliated sites, linked sites, and advertisements](#Affiliated_sites,_linked_sites,_and_advertisements)
* [7 Your Consent](#Your_Consent)
* [8 Children](#Children)
* [9 Contacting Us](#Contacting_Us)
* [10 Changes to this Policy](#Changes_to_this_Policy)
* [11 Governing Law](#Governing_Law)

Privacy Policy – What information do we collect from you?
---------------------------------------------------------

We collect information from you when you register on our site or fill out a form. When registering on our site, as appropriate, you may be asked to enter your name, e-mail address, mailing address, and/or phone number. You may, however, visit our site anonymously.

What do we use your information for?
------------------------------------

Any of the information we collect from you may be used in one of the following ways:

* To personalize your experience. Your information helps us to better respond to your individual needs.

* We will use the personal information that we have collected to fulfill the objective for which the information was collected unless we have your written consent to use it for some other purpose.

* We will save the personal information so long as it is necessary or helpful for fulfilling the purpose for which we have collected it.

* The information will be collected by lawful and fair means, and of course with the consent and awareness of the affected individual.

* To improve our website. We continually strive to improve our website offerings based on the information and any feedback we receive from you.

Do We Use Cookies?
------------------

Yes. Cookies are small files that a site or its service provider transfers to your computer’s hard drive through your web browser (if you allow) that enables the site’s or service provider’s systems to recognize your browser and capture and remember certain information.

For instance, we use cookies to tell us about your last visit to our site in order for us to improve our site upon your next visit. They are also used to help us understand your preferences based on previous or current site activity, which enables us to provide you with improved services.

We also use cookies to help us compile aggregate data about site traffic and site interaction so that we can offer better site experiences and tools in the future. We may contract with third-party service providers, including Google, to assist us in better understanding our site visitors, and possibly to show you ads on sites on the internet based on your preference during your prior visit on our site. These service providers are not permitted to use the information collected on our behalf except to help us conduct and improve our business. You can choose to have your computer warn you each time a cookie is being sent, or you can choose to turn off all cookies. You do this through your browser (like Firefox or Internet Explorer) settings. Each browser is a little different, so look at your browser Help menu to learn the correct way to modify your cookies. If you turn cookies off, you may not have access to some features that make your site experience more efficient, and some of our services may not function properly.

How do we protect your information?
-----------------------------------

We implement a variety of security measures to maintain the safety of your personal information when you enter, submit, or access your personal information. One of the methods we use is the SSL or Secure Sockets Layer to make sure your personal and credit card information is safe online.

Do we disclose any information to outside parties?
--------------------------------------------------

We do not sell, rent, trade, or otherwise transfer to outside parties your personally identifiable information. This does not include trusted third parties who assist us in operating our website, conducting our business, or servicing you, so long as those parties agree to keep this information confidential. We may also release your information when we believe release is appropriate to comply with the law, enforce our site policies, or protect our or others’ rights, property, or safety. However, non-personally identifiable visitor information may be provided to other parties for marketing, advertising, or other uses.

Affiliated sites, linked sites, and advertisements
--------------------------------------------------

Our Company expects its partners, advertisers and affiliates to respect the privacy of our users. Be aware, however, that third parties, including our partners, advertisers, affiliates and other content providers accessible through our site, may have their own privacy and data collection policies and practices. For example, during your visit to our site you may link to, or view as part of a frame on a unifiedmindfulness.com page, certain content that is actually created or hosted by a third party.

Also, through unifiedmindfulness.com you may be introduced to, or be able to access, information, websites, features, or contests offered by other parties. Our Company is not responsible for the actions or policies of such third parties. You should check the applicable privacy policies of those third parties when providing information on a feature or page operated by a third party. While on our site, our advertisers, promotional partners, or other third parties may use cookies or other technology to attempt to identify some of your preferences or retrieve information about you. For example, some of our advertising is served by third parties and may include cookies that enable the advertiser to determine whether you have seen a particular advertisement before. Other features available on our site may offer services operated by third parties and may use cookies or other technology to gather information. Our Company does not control the use of this technology by third parties or the resulting information, and is not responsible for any actions or policies of such third parties. You should also be aware that if you voluntarily disclose personally identifiable Information on message boards or in chat areas, that information can be viewed publicly and can be collected and used by third parties without our knowledge and may result in unsolicited messages from other individuals or third parties. Such activities are beyond the control of unifiedmindfulness.com and the scope of this policy.

Your Consent
------------

By using our site, you consent to this Privacy Policy. It is understood that you have read, and agreed to, the Privacy Policy before entering your information.

Children
--------

Unifiedmindfulness.com does not knowingly collect or solicit personally identifiable information from or about children under 18 except as permitted by law. If we discover we have received any information from a child under 18 in violation of this policy, we will delete that information immediately. If you believe unifiedmindfulness.com has any information from or about anyone under the age of 18, please contact us at the address listed below.

Contacting Us
-------------

We can be reached:

on the Web at <https://unifiedmindfulness.com/contact-us/>

via email at: [[email protected]](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection)

or via post mail at the following address:

UM-HUB LLC
PO Box 283
Charlotte, VT 05445

Changes to this Policy
----------------------

We reserve the right to change this policy at any time. Please check this page periodically for changes. Your continued use of our site following the posting of changes to these terms will mean you accept those changes. Information collected prior to the time any change is posted will be used according to the rules and laws that applied at the time the information was collected.

Governing Law
-------------

THIS POLICY AND THE USE OF THIS SITE ARE GOVERNED BY CALIFORNIA LAW. IF A DISPUTE ARISES UNDER THIS POLICY WE AGREE TO FIRST TRY TO RESOLVE IT WITH THE HELP OF A MUTUALLY AGREED-UPON MEDIATOR IN THE FOLLOWING LOCATION: LOS ANGELES COUNTY. ANY COSTS AND FEES OTHER THAN ATTORNEY FEES ASSOCIATED WITH THE MEDIATION WILL BE SHARED EQUALLY BY EACH OF US. IF IT PROVES IMPOSSIBLE TO ARRIVE AT A MUTUALLY SATISFACTORY SOLUTION THROUGH MEDIATION, WE AGREE TO SUBMIT THE DISPUTE TO BINDING ARBITRATION AT THE FOLLOWING LOCATION: LOS ANGELES COUNTY, UNDER THE RULES OF THE AMERICAN ARBITRATION ASSOCIATION. JUDGMENT UPON THE AWARD RENDERED BY THE ARBITRATION MAY BE ENTERED IN ANY COURT WITH JURISDICTION TO DO SO. OUR COMPANY AND THIS WEBSITE ARE CONTROLLED, OPERATED AND ADMINISTERED WITHIN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA. THIS STATEMENT AND THE POLICIES OUTLINED HEREIN ARE NOT INTENDED TO AND DO NOT CREATE ANY CONTRACTUAL OR OTHER LEGAL RIGHTS IN OR ON BEHALF OF ANY PARTY.

Response Challenge - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Response Challenge
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Response Challenge** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four Accelerators. Allows you to systematically explore your inner system (or parts of it) in reaction to a sight, sound, or touch in your environment in preparation for when they come up unpredictably in everyday life. You can control the stimulus by type (i.e., sight, sound, touch, or some combination), hedonic valence (i.e., pleasant, unpleasant, both, or neither), intensity, duration, and length of time between exposures. For example, you could listen to music or watch the news and then intentionally apply a technique to turn toward or anchor away from any inner activation. |
| **Synonyms** | [Trigger Practice (old term)](/index.php/Trigger_Practice_(old_term) "Trigger Practice (old term)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Situation Challenge](/index.php/Situation_Challenge "Situation Challenge"), [Recycle the Reaction](/index.php/Recycle_the_Reaction "Recycle the Reaction"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Vicious and Virtuous Cycle](/index.php?title=Vicious_and_Virtuous_Cycle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vicious and Virtuous Cycle (page does not exist)"), [Feel Good](/index.php/Feel_Good "Feel Good"), [Feedback](/index.php?title=Feedback&action=edit&redlink=1 "Feedback (page does not exist)"), [In/Out](/index.php/In/Out "In/Out"), [SHF In/SHF Out](/index.php?title=SHF_In/SHF_Out&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF In/SHF Out (page does not exist)") |

Special Exercise - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Special Exercise
================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Special Exercise** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Any mindfulness technique that is not a Standard Unified Mindfulness technique. Can be classified in the ULTRA Grid by comparing it with UM Standard Techniques and themes. From the perspective of UM, meditation techniques that aren’t *Standard* can include:  1. Techniques that can be used repeatedly or in many situations that are already in common use and were designed using UM concepts or technical terms. For instance, See Hear Feel Drive, Note General Level of X, the POP analysis for See In (Person Object Place), or Naming Feel In sensations (Anger, Fear, Sadness, etc.) 2. *Warm-Ups* or *Steps* related to Standard Techniques such as Just Note New/Gone for SHF Now, Note Mind Activity for Auto Think, or Sensitizing Exercises such as a Tour of the Senses or exploring the Zoom Noting Option in Feel, etc. 3. *Custom Techniques* any individual may design using UM methods (e.g., intentionally including CC&E skill development) for repeated use in specific settings or with a certain audience or client. For instance, you’re working with athletes doing a specific sport, so you tailor techniques to fit that sport. Or, you’re working with a population struggling with a specific health challenge, like diabetes, so you tailor techniques to fit that population. Or you’re working with a client around an ongoing behavior change like improving their diet. 4. *Custom Techniques* that may be designed for clients on the spot and may not be transferable for general or ongoing use. For instance, your client has a unique window come up—their hands get very vivid and seem to expand to take up a lot of space—so you design the *Expanding Hands* technique for them, on the fly, to work with the experience which may or may not come up again. 5. *Outside Techniques* that do not use UM design methods and have been developed in other approaches such as a T.M. mantra, U Ba Khin/MBSR style body sweeping, Christian contemplative prayer, Wim Hoff method, etc. 6. Mindfulness Techniques that have been mixed with other healing modalities. For instance, MBCT (Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy) is not just a mindfulness technique; it includes other elements that aren’t related to mindfulness practice. In these cases it’s critical to tease apart what is mindfulness meditation and what is not. If you’re not a licensed therapist, you don’t offer MBCT in a professional setting. Those boundaries must be clearly maintained. Also, to prevent confusion and other complications (for instance, liability), if you are a cross-discipline trainer, you need to clearly explain to clients what aspect of what you’re teaching is mindfulness and what is not. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [General Level of X](/index.php?title=General_Level_of_X&action=edit&redlink=1 "General Level of X (page does not exist)"), [Warmup](/index.php?title=Warmup&action=edit&redlink=1 "Warmup (page does not exist)"), [Sensitizing Exercise](/index.php?title=Sensitizing_Exercise&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sensitizing Exercise (page does not exist)"), [Tour of the Senses](/index.php?title=Tour_of_the_Senses&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tour of the Senses (page does not exist)"), [Standard Technique](/index.php/Standard_Technique "Standard Technique"), [Technique](/index.php/Technique "Technique"), [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options"), [ION](/index.php/ION "ION"), [Focus Range and Instruction Set](/index.php?title=Focus_Range_and_Instruction_Set&action=edit&redlink=1 "Focus Range and Instruction Set (page does not exist)"), [4 Rs](/index.php?title=4_Rs&action=edit&redlink=1 "4 Rs (page does not exist)"), [3 Cs](/index.php?title=3_Cs&action=edit&redlink=1 "3 Cs (page does not exist)"), [ULTRA](/index.php/ULTRA "ULTRA") |

Grayscale
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Grayscale** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The darkness and/or brightness in front of and/or behind your closed eyes, which is a form of visual rest. It could be mainly dark or bright, a mixture of the two, or some gray tone in between. It may be uniform, blotchy or pixelated, stable or flowing. Technically, it is a mixture of physical light coming through from the outside, mixed with darkness or brightness from the “source of consciousness,” and can be considered a mixture of inner and outer visual rest. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Inner Visual Rest](/index.php/Inner_Visual_Rest "Inner Visual Rest"), [See Rest](/index.php/See_Rest "See Rest"), [See In](/index.php/See_In "See In"), [See Out](/index.php/See_Out "See Out") |

Absolute Now - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Absolute Now
============

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Absolute Now** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. **A Temporary State: Form as Formlessness.** What mainly registers in your senses is non-separateness of form, even as form is being experienced. A single term that covers any way you may try to describe form reflecting formlessness (see the graph in Benefits—Absolute). A catchall UM term mainly used to connect the SHF Now technique to all the related UM terms for talking about the Absolute, including Absolute Activity (aka, Deep Expansion/Contraction Flow), Deep Spontaneity, and Absolute Rest. Sometimes Absolute experience is reflected by the senses in a way that seems to highlight the perception of spatial non-separateness, which the term Absolute Activity points to. Sometimes the Absolute is reflected in the senses in a way that seems to highlight the effortless just happening of experience, which the term deep Spontaneity points to. Whether you’re aware of it or not, always within and beyond any reflection of the Absolute (and all experience) is Absolute Rest—formlessness. Absolute Now covers any way form may reflect the formless, including how the Absolute may also be reflected in the theme of timelessness, as in Now with a capital N (see below), or other absences (for instance, the absence of a sense of fixed identity—No Self). 2. **A Temporary State: Time as Formlessness.** As a reflection of the Absolute, the present moment is experienced free from the construct of time. Now, with a capital N. When subtle sensory interference that causes the solidified impression of time drops away, you can experience being free from the constraints of a timeline. This happens on the surface of your awareness. As a result, you can come to know time as a useful construct and nothing more. When you perceive time as formlessness, what you mainly perceive is timelessness—no construct of time. You might experience that as *everything is always just happening **now*** or ***next** is just a story the mind creates*, or *there is no **before** because you can’t hold on to experience*. What is reflected in the senses is the absence of time as a thing. Timelessness, deep Spontaneity, and Absolute Activity all point to the same freedom from form. They are different ways to describe the Absolute, based on how the Absolute is being reflected in the senses. 3. **A Sensory Trait.** Non-separateness is a trait that gets uncovered through raising your baseline CC&E. With enough CC&E, it becomes clear that solidified, *ordinary* reality is a temporary (though chronic) state caused by sensory interference. Due to conditioning, the constructed stories of the mind are repeatedly overvalued and reinforced. But that’s just a force of habit. Since non-separateness is a sensory trait, in every moment of your ordinary day there is the chance to discover or uncover the extraordinary. ***Now*** is always available, whether you’re able to access it or not. When you’re more free to fully disappear into every experience you have and every activity you do—because your self is not a solid, separate thing—your surface awareness lines up with deep experience because nothing gets in the way. All of sensory experience right at the surface of awareness becomes the one basic activity—the activity of two fused opposites—which some people call the loving activity. All sensory systems have this hidden potential because non-interference is a basic trait of the system. 4. **A Deepening Attainment.** The process of integrating transcendence into the dynamic activity of everyday life. Part of this is experiential—you detect the Absolute more clearly and consistently throughout your day. Another important part of this is the ability to *Manifest*. More and more, you manifest the dynamic activity of Absolute Now spontaneously. It’s effortlessly expressed through you. It just happens. As you discover the underlying trait of non-separateness in all phases of experience, and over the years and decades of training, your everyday experience tends to shift to more consistently clear, surface-level awareness of non-separateness (Absolute Now/Rest), which you can access more and more, by choice. In daily life, contact with the Absolute is mixed with more solidified experience, and more solidified experience comes to be perceived through the lens of human positivity, or love (whatever word rings true for you). Meaning, there is no preference because all sensory experience is loved. This affects the way you manifest in the world. As a result of loving all experience you manifest human positivity more fully. More and more you become the Magic Robot. 5. **A Focus Range.** Direct Pointing (Point) techniques may take formless Spontaneity—sensory activity reflecting the Absolute—as their Focus Range. You could define the focus range of the SHF Now family of techniques and the Auto family of techniques as deep E/C Flow, and/or Deep Spontaneity, in Perception or Expression. (Typically, the focus range of these techniques are defined in a more surface way so they can be accessible for anyone to practice them and as sensitizing exercises for deep experience.) Defining the focus range as Absolute Now means you would need to be able to contact the Absolute by choice (see Definition 4). A Trainer may choose to emphasize this deeper context of the Absolute as the Focus Range of SHF Now, or the more surface focus range, depending on your specific audience. 6. **The Deepest Phase of Spontaneity.** Deep Spontaneity is a way to describe the effortless just happeningness of experience that goes beyond just Perception or just Expression. At a more surface level, UM tends to tie the word Spontaneity to Expression. At the level of Absolute Now—the deepest phase of experience in which form reflects formlessness—what UM calls Perception and Expression are fused. As a framework for training your skills, Perception and Expression fall under the bigger umbrella of Sensory Experience and they’re only divided up for the purpose of exploring the two contrasting sides of Sensory Input and Sensory Output, independently. Perception and Expression are disentangled from each other so you can selectively focus on them. On an experiential level, there can come a point when, at the surface of conscious awareness, there’s no separation between what UM calls Perception and Expression, because there’s clear non-separateness between all sensory experience. So even though on the surface spontaneity is connected to Expression, at the deepest level, Spontaneity points to non-separateness of all Sensory Experience, and how Perception and Expression are one and the same. From that perspective, the term Deep Spontaneity can also be considered a synonym for deep Expansion/Contraction Flow. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |

Note Level of Experience - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Note Level of Experience
========================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Note Level of Experience** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A Special Exercise in which you track the intensity of a given experience (i.e., how strong or weak it is at any given moment). This contrasts with many standard UM techniques where you track by sense category (SHF) or other qualities of those experiences (locations, activity vs. rest, flow, spaciousness, etc.). For example, you could note the moment-by-moment intensity of a particular kind of experience, such as a particular emotion (like embarrassment), thought pattern (like worrying about the future), or urge (like, *I need to buy that thing right now*). The experience can be simple or complex, clear or unclear, pleasant, unpleasant, mixed, or neutral. Common labels are *Clear*, *Subtle*, *None* (or *Strong*, *Weak*, *None*). Can also be numbers (for example, 1-5). |
| **Synonyms** | [Note General Level of X](/index.php/Note_General_Level_of_X "Note General Level of X") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Special Exercises](/index.php?title=Special_Exercises&action=edit&redlink=1 "Special Exercises (page does not exist)"), [Sensory Clarity](/index.php/Sensory_Clarity "Sensory Clarity"), [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [How much of what](/index.php?title=How_much_of_what&action=edit&redlink=1 "How much of what (page does not exist)"), [when](/index.php?title=When&action=edit&redlink=1 "When (page does not exist)"), [where](/index.php?title=Where&action=edit&redlink=1 "Where (page does not exist)"), [changing in what ways](/index.php?title=Changing_in_what_ways&action=edit&redlink=1 "Changing in what ways (page does not exist)"), [and interacting in what ways](/index.php?title=And_interacting_in_what_ways&action=edit&redlink=1 "And interacting in what ways (page does not exist)") |

How Much of What-When-Where-Changing in What Ways-Interacting in What Ways - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


How Much of What-When-Where-Changing in What Ways-Interacting in What Ways
==========================================================================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **How Much of What-When-Where-Changing in What Ways-Interacting in What Ways** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | In the UM system, a handy science-informed list of six ways to discern and detect experience with Sensory Clarity, at a more fine-grained level. For any sensory experience:  *How Much* means amount, measured by level of intensity (see Local Intensity & Wider Spread).  *What* means its quality or qualities (although the UM definition for Quality is intentionally broader. See Quality).  *When* means detecting it as close as possible to Now (one way is by noting New and Gone).  *Where* means locating it in space (See Spatiality/Space).  *Changing in What Ways* means tracking its Flow, regardless of phase (see Flow).  *Interacting in What Ways* means what it’s influencing and being influenced by (see Deconstruct, Local Intensity & Wider Spread, Vicious & Virtuous Cycles, Triggers). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Sensory Clarity](/index.php/Sensory_Clarity "Sensory Clarity"), [Local Intensity & Wider Spread](/index.php?title=Local_Intensity_%26_Wider_Spread&action=edit&redlink=1 "Local Intensity & Wider Spread (page does not exist)"), [Spatiality](/index.php?title=Spatiality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Spatiality (page does not exist)"), [Quality](/index.php?title=Quality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Quality (page does not exist)"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow"), [Deconstruct](/index.php/Deconstruct "Deconstruct"), [Local Intensity & Wider Spread](/index.php?title=Local_Intensity_%26_Wider_Spread&action=edit&redlink=1 "Local Intensity & Wider Spread (page does not exist)"), [Vicious vs. Virtuous Cycle](/index.php?title=Vicious_vs._Virtuous_Cycle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vicious vs. Virtuous Cycle (page does not exist)") |

Technique Options
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Technique Options** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Specific choices you can make while practicing a technique to help you work with windows and/or walls, or to help make practice fun, interesting, and/or more productive (i.e., based on ION). Can be standard (i.e., included in the instructions of a standard technique, such as re-noting or zooming) or designer (i.e., you can create a custom element such as noting gone while practicing the SHF technique). Doesn’t include choices within a focus range, for example, the choice to focus on physical relaxation, absence of sensation, or emotional neutrality in the Feel Rest technique, or technique ingredients that are hardwired into the instruction set, such as using an Even Coverage contact strategy in Auto Think. |

Windows - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Windows
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Windows** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Reward states as well as other openings which can help you deepen your practice. You could call them spontaneous pointers from nature. The three types include:  1. Experiences that are generally considered pleasant, such as restfulness and emotional wellbeing. 2. States that point to unity or transcendence such as general flow, spaciousness, spontaneity, expansion/contraction flow, or something else. Your experience of these states may be pleasant, unpleasant, both, or neither, and there may be a learning curve to integrate them. 3. When you recognize any individual attention skill (either Concentration, Clarity, or Equanimity) or any combination of them, as being rewarding.   Pairs with Walls. |
| **Synonyms** | [Opportunities (Windows is preferred)](/index.php/Opportunities_(Windows_is_preferred) "Opportunities (Windows is preferred)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Strategize](/index.php?title=Strategize&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strategize (page does not exist)"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Reward State](/index.php?title=Reward_State&action=edit&redlink=1 "Reward State (page does not exist)"), [CC&E Rewards](/index.php?title=CC%26E_Rewards&action=edit&redlink=1 "CC&E Rewards (page does not exist)"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Windows&oldid=2120>"

Feel Good - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Feel Good
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Feel Good** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Nurture Positive (NP) quadrant that focuses attention on positive emotions in the body. May involve finding positive emotions or using a range of methods to generate them (*Find the spark or Reach for the STARS—Smile, Think, Activate, Respond, or Support positivity*). Uses sustained concentration since you focus on positive emotional body sensations for as long as they last. 2. Shorthand for positive emotional experience in the body, as in, *I’ve got a lot of Feel Good hearing you say those kind words.* |
| **Synonyms** | [Pleasant Feel In](/index.php/Pleasant_Feel_In "Pleasant Feel In"), [Positive Feel In](/index.php/Positive_Feel_In "Positive Feel In"), [Pleasant Emotion](/index.php/Pleasant_Emotion "Pleasant Emotion") |
| **Antonyms** | [Negativity](/index.php?title=Negativity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Negativity (page does not exist)") |
| **Related** | [Nurture Positive (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Nurture_Positive_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nurture Positive (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [See Good](/index.php/See_Good "See Good"), [Hear Good](/index.php?title=Hear_Good&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hear Good (page does not exist)"), [Be Good](/index.php/Be_Good "Be Good"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Evoke](/index.php?title=Evoke&action=edit&redlink=1 "Evoke (page does not exist)"), [Feel In](/index.php/Feel_In "Feel In"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits") |

Just See/Hear/Feel - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Just See/Hear/Feel
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Just See/Hear/Feel** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Techniques in the Appreciate quadrant that focus attention exclusively on one sense category (i.e., See, or Hear, or Feel) including inner and outer, active and restful aspects of that sense category.  1. *Just See*: Focuses attention exclusively on See, inner/outer, active/restful, leaving Hear and Feel in the background. 2. *Just Hear*: Focuses attention exclusively on Hear, inner/outer, active/restful, leaving See and Feel in the background. 3. *Just Feel*: Focuses attention exclusively on Feel, inner/outer, active/restful, leaving See and Hear in the background.   Together, Just See, Just Hear, Just Feel, and See Hear Feel form the See Hear Feel Technique Family. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See Hear Feel Family of Techniques](/index.php?title=See_Hear_Feel_Family_of_Techniques&action=edit&redlink=1 "See Hear Feel Family of Techniques (page does not exist)") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Just_See/Hear/Feel&oldid=2092>"

Mindfulness Training - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Mindfulness Training
====================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Mindfulness Training** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A framework for mindfulness practice that includes four parts:  1. *Technique Set*: You have to have at least one focus technique and if you have more than one you need to understand how the different techniques you use work together. 2. *Training Structure*: Life practice (Formal and Informal), Retreat Practice, Get Support, Give Support. Together, these make up the Four Pillars of Practice. (See Finer Details below.) 3. *Happiness Goals*: Aspects of happiness that you would like to improve through practice (these may broaden and deepen with time). 4. *Understanding the Mechanism*: The ability to connect the dots (i.e., how developing mindfulness skills and using mindfulness strategies supports achieving your Happiness Goals). |
| **Synonyms** | [Mindfulness Practice](/index.php/Mindfulness_Practice "Mindfulness Practice") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Four Pillars (of Practice)](/index.php?title=Four_Pillars_(of_Practice)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Four Pillars (of Practice) (page does not exist)"), [Happiness Grid](/index.php/Happiness_Grid "Happiness Grid") |

See Hear Feel In - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


See Hear Feel In
================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **See Hear Feel In** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. A technique in the Appreciate quadrant that focuses attention on activity and rest in See In, Hear In, and Feel In. Sometimes called Focus In. 2. Shorthand for sensory experience in the inner spaces, which includes:  * See In (thoughts you See and inner See Rest) * Hear In (thoughts you Hear and inner Hear Rest) * Feel In (emotions you Feel in the body and emotional peace, aka inner Feel Rest)   Commonly called the Inner System. |
| **Synonyms** | [SHF In](/index.php/SHF_In "SHF In"), [Focus In](/index.php/Focus_In "Focus In"), [Inner System](/index.php/Inner_System "Inner System") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See Hear Feel](/index.php?title=See_Hear_Feel&action=edit&redlink=1 "See Hear Feel (page does not exist)"), [See In](/index.php/See_In "See In"), [Hear In](/index.php/Hear_In "Hear In"), [Feel In](/index.php/Feel_In "Feel In"), [Inner System](/index.php/Inner_System "Inner System"), [thoughts & emotions](/index.php?title=Thoughts_%26_emotions&action=edit&redlink=1 "Thoughts & emotions (page does not exist)"), [See Hear Feel Out](/index.php/See_Hear_Feel_Out "See Hear Feel Out"), [Deconstruct](/index.php/Deconstruct "Deconstruct") |

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Feel
====

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Feel** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | 1. What you experience in the body physically (Feel Out), such as feet on the ground or physical relaxation, including taste and smell, or what you experience in the body emotionally (Feel In), such as excitement in the chest or emotional peace. 2. A flexible label used in many techniques. 3. Short for the category name for body experience. |
| **Synonyms** | [Somatic](/index.php/Somatic "Somatic"), [Body Experience](/index.php/Body_Experience "Body Experience"), [Feel space](/index.php/Feel_space "Feel space") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Sense Category](/index.php/Sense_Category "Sense Category"), [See](/index.php/See "See"), [Hear](/index.php/Hear "Hear"), [Just Feel](/index.php/Just_Feel "Just Feel"), [Feel In](/index.php/Feel_In "Feel In"), [Feel Out](/index.php/Feel_Out "Feel Out"), [Feel Flow](/index.php/Feel_Flow "Feel Flow"), [Feel Good](/index.php/Feel_Good "Feel Good"), [Auto Move](/index.php/Auto_Move "Auto Move") |

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Times of Your Life
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Times of Your Life** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A handy list of ways to group common daily life situations so you can decide how to work with them. Includes the categories:  * Golden Times—ideal for practice, such as exercise or eating * Down Times—waiting, such as in line or before a meeting * Connection Times—anything social or with a pet * Stress Times—times you consider stressful * Physical Times—simple physical movement, such as brushing your teeth * Mind Times—active thinking such as problem solving, working on computer |
| **Synonyms** | ['''UM Times of Your Life Inventory'''](/index.php?title=%27%27%27UM_Times_of_Your_Life_Inventory%27%27%27&action=edit&redlink=1 "'''UM Times of Your Life Inventory''' (page does not exist)") |
