Active and Restful - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Active and Restful
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Active and Restful** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | UM classifies two main kinds of sensory experience, which represent two sides of a spectrum: Active and Restful. Active can happen on its own spectrum from subtle or neutral to intense and/or complex. For instance, the touch of the clothes on the skin as compared to the sound of a foghorn. Restful can happen on its own spectrum from not much detected to detecting the complete absence of sensory experience. For example, noticing that your body feels relaxed as compared to noticing that your torso doesn’t seem to be there at all because you can’t detect any sensation in your torso. Active and Restful can also be contrasted relative to each other, in terms of amount, as in more or less sensation (for example, my hands are restful as opposed to active because I don’t detect much sensation there). But they can also be contrasted by the type of sensory experiences, which show up differently in each sense category.  **Active Experiences:**   * For See, inner activity is represented by mental images; outer activity is represented by physical sights. * For Hear, inner activity is represented by mental talk; outer activity is represented by physical sound. * For Feel, inner activity is represented by body sensations that are obviously emotional to you in that moment; outer activity is represented by any type of physical body sensation.   **Restful Experiences:**   * For See, inner rest includes looking in but not at, looking at the grayscale (which is technically a combination of inner and outer because of physical light coming through the eyes), or noticing the absence of mental images; outer rest includes looking out but not at. * For Hear, inner rest is the quiet mind; outer rest is the silent environment. * For Feel, inner rest is the absence of emotional sensation, or emotional neutrality, or peace; outer rest is the absence of physical sensation, or the quality of relaxation (there may be flow in relaxation which is either active or restful depending on how you perceive it). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [See In](/index.php/See_In "See In"), [See Out](/index.php/See_Out "See Out"), [Hear In](/index.php/Hear_In "Hear In"), [Hear Out](/index.php/Hear_Out "Hear Out"), [Feel In](/index.php/Feel_In "Feel In"), [Feel Out](/index.php/Feel_Out "Feel Out"), [Restful State](/index.php?title=Restful_State&action=edit&redlink=1 "Restful State (page does not exist)"), [Sensory Activity](/index.php?title=Sensory_Activity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sensory Activity (page does not exist)") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Active_and_Restful&oldid=2019>"

Stretch Up and Settle In - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Stretch Up and Settle In
========================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Stretch Up and Settle In** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A phrase about posture that Shinzen frequently uses at the beginning and during his guided meditations. Reminds you that balancing alertness and relaxation in a posture helps deepen practice. Applies to any posture, including sitting, standing, lying down, and more. (If you’re practicing while standing still, for example, you’d stretch the upper body and then let everything hang from the central pillar. If you’re lying down, you can still slightly raise your arms and legs and then drop them, once again creating a global sense of relaxation.) |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Posture](/index.php?title=Posture&action=edit&redlink=1 "Posture (page does not exist)"), [Guidance](/index.php?title=Guidance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Guidance (page does not exist)"), [Strong Determination Sitting](/index.php?title=Strong_Determination_Sitting&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strong Determination Sitting (page does not exist)"), [Duration Challenge](/index.php/Duration_Challenge "Duration Challenge"), [Feel Out](/index.php/Feel_Out "Feel Out") |

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Informal Practice
=================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Informal Practice** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A period of practice that either lasts for less than 10 minutes or in which only a portion of your attention is on the technique, while you're mainly focusing on whatever other activity you're doing (such as having a conversation or working on your computer).  1. Microhits are performed with heightened attention, but can be quite short—a few minutes, or even a few seconds. 2. Background practice can be performed for any length of time, but you’re putting just some of your attention on doing the technique. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Formal Practice](/index.php/Formal_Practice "Formal Practice"), [Modes of Practice](/index.php?title=Modes_of_Practice&action=edit&redlink=1 "Modes of Practice (page does not exist)"), [Microhit](/index.php/Microhit "Microhit"), [Background Practice](/index.php/Background_Practice "Background Practice"), [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA") |

Virtuous and Vicious Cycles - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Virtuous and Vicious Cycles
===========================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Virtuous and Vicious Cycles** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | Positive and negative patterns of cause and effect. Becoming clear about them relates to the “interacting in what ways” part of Sensory Clarity. Detecting how these important cycles work improves your understanding of mindfulness practice and its outcomes, so you suffer less, deepen your fulfillment, and act more effectively, which tends to lead to better outcomes in the world. **Example of a Virtuous Cycle:** Your body feels relaxed and you’re in good spirits emotionally, which comes out in your voice and body language when you’re talking with a friend. Your friend picks up on your state, which boosts their spirits, so the conversation moves in fun directions. You enjoy that, which deepens your emotional positivity and relaxation.  **Example of a Vicious Cycle:** You see an unpleasant post on social media which causes you emotional pain. You don’t know how to work with the pain, so you try to push it away. You start arguing with the post in your mind, which increases your agitation. Fifteen minutes later, you feel drained. A co-worker asks you for something and you snap at them before you can catch yourself. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Suffering = Pain × Resistance](/index.php?title=Suffering_%3D_Pain_%C3%97_Resistance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Suffering = Pain × Resistance (page does not exist)"), [Fulfillment = Pleasure × Equanimity](/index.php?title=Fulfillment_%3D_Pleasure_%C3%97_Equanimity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fulfillment = Pleasure × Equanimity (page does not exist)"), [Positive/Negative Feedback Loop](/index.php?title=Positive/Negative_Feedback_Loop&action=edit&redlink=1 "Positive/Negative Feedback Loop (page does not exist)"), [Rewards](/index.php/Rewards "Rewards"), [Hedonic Valence](/index.php/Hedonic_Valence "Hedonic Valence"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits"), [Micro Check](/index.php?title=Micro_Check&action=edit&redlink=1 "Micro Check (page does not exist)") |





Retrieved from "<https://wiki.unifiedmindfulness.com/index.php?title=Virtuous_and_Vicious_Cycles&oldid=1820>"

![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Situation Challenge
===================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Situation Challenge** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the four Accelerators. Trains your ability to apply an intentional strategy to a life situation. The situation could be pleasant or unpleasant, big or small, personal or global, short-lived or long-lasting. It could be a situation you seek out (like your exercise routine) or one that happens to you (you go to the hospital, your candidate wins or loses). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Motion Challenge](/index.php/Motion_Challenge "Motion Challenge"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Duration Challenge](/index.php/Duration_Challenge "Duration Challenge"), [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [Momentum Practice](/index.php/Momentum_Practice "Momentum Practice"), [Times of Your Life](/index.php/Times_of_Your_Life "Times of Your Life"), [ASIA](/index.php/ASIA "ASIA"), [Setting Options](/index.php/Setting_Options "Setting Options"), [Practice Maturity](/index.php/Practice_Maturity "Practice Maturity"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls"), [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [ION](/index.php/ION "ION"), [Recycle the Reaction](/index.php/Recycle_the_Reaction "Recycle the Reaction"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits") |

Re-noting - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Re-noting
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Re-noting** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | An option for noting the same sensory event more than once while practicing any noting technique. May happen in these ways:  1. When you plan ahead to note each sensory experience a set number of times for all or part of a practice session. Common options include Double Note, Triple Note, Quad Note, or Note until Gone (i.e., noting a given experience until all or part vanishes). 2. When you decide on the spot during a practice to intentionally place your attention on a given experience again (with the option to choose a set number of times or not particularly keep track). 3. When you don’t make a decision but you find yourself repeatedly noting the same experience because your attention keeps getting drawn to it. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Noting](/index.php/Noting "Noting"), [Labeling](/index.php/Labeling "Labeling"), [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options") |

Zooming - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Zooming
=======

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Zooming** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | An option for controlling the spatial scope of your focus that can be used with any technique. May happen in these ways:  1. Zoom In to narrow your focus. 2. Zoom Out to broaden your focus. 3. Zoom Both Ways to put some attention on a narrow region or local intensity, while at the same time spreading your attention more broadly.   These spatial adjustments with your attention help clarify the full extent as well as all the parts of the sensory event (Clarity). They can also encourage conscious or subconscious spread (Equanimity). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Technique Options](/index.php/Technique_Options "Technique Options"), [Spatiality](/index.php?title=Spatiality&action=edit&redlink=1 "Spatiality (page does not exist)"), [Local Intensity & Wider Spread](/index.php?title=Local_Intensity_%26_Wider_Spread&action=edit&redlink=1 "Local Intensity & Wider Spread (page does not exist)"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Walls](/index.php/Walls "Walls") |

Neutrality - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Neutrality
==========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Neutrality** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | The word neutrality doesn’t have a technical meaning in UM, but people may use it as a way to talk about experience. Since it can have different meanings in different contexts, you may need to do a Definition Check when it’s being used. The most common usages include:   1. A sensory experience that is neither pleasant nor unpleasant may be called *neutral* (i.e., hedonically neutral). 2. The absence of emotional sensation in the body may be called *emotional neutrality* (i.e., as a synonym for Emotional Peace). 3. The absence of any sensation in the body may be called *neutral* (e.g., *I don’t really feel anything where my ears are. It’s just neutral.*). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [Rest](/index.php?title=Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rest (page does not exist)"), [Feel Rest](/index.php/Feel_Rest "Feel Rest"), [Emotional Peace](/index.php/Emotional_Peace "Emotional Peace"), [Hedonic Check](/index.php?title=Hedonic_Check&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hedonic Check (page does not exist)"), [Hedonic Valence](/index.php/Hedonic_Valence "Hedonic Valence"), [Hedonic Tone](/index.php/Hedonic_Tone "Hedonic Tone"), [Upekkha](/index.php?title=Upekkha&action=edit&redlink=1 "Upekkha (page does not exist)") |

Equanimity - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Equanimity
==========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Equanimity** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the three core attention skills, the ability to allow sensory experience to come and go without push and pull. Can be developed through a range of methods, such as noticing when it happens spontaneously, dropping judgments, intentionally relaxing, non-interference, anchoring attention away, noticing disappearances, creating or collapsing distance between yourself and a focus object (through zooming, being the *witness*, etc.), or accessing a positive emotional state, such as gratitude, compassion, etc.  **Foreground/Background:** You may be focusing directly on a sensory experience or you may be allowing a sensory experience to come and go freely in the background.   * Background: Equanimity applied to any and all sensory experience outside of the focus range (in distraction space). Practiced by allowing experience to come and go freely in the background of attention. * Foreground: Applying Equanimity directly to a sensory experience. May be induced with physical relaxation, a matter-of-fact tone in labels, any welcoming or accepting attitude, zooming, or designer options. Pairs with Background Equanimity.   **Deep Equanimity:** A way to talk about transcendence. There is so little friction in the sensory system that sensory experience of form is completely effortless, spontaneous, and non-separate, and sensory awareness of no form is so complete, there is not even light. |
| **Synonyms** | [Coolness](/index.php/Coolness "Coolness"), [Non-resistance](/index.php/Non-resistance "Non-resistance"), [Non-interference](/index.php/Non-interference "Non-interference"), [Equanimous (adjective)](/index.php/Equanimous_(adjective) "Equanimous (adjective)"), [Equanimize (verb)](/index.php/Equanimize_(verb) "Equanimize (verb)"), [Love](/index.php/Love "Love") |
| **Antonyms** | [Resistance](/index.php?title=Resistance&action=edit&redlink=1 "Resistance (page does not exist)"), [Self-interference](/index.php?title=Self-interference&action=edit&redlink=1 "Self-interference (page does not exist)"), [Sticky](/index.php?title=Sticky&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sticky (page does not exist)"), [Fixated](/index.php?title=Fixated&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fixated (page does not exist)"), [Coagulated](/index.php?title=Coagulated&action=edit&redlink=1 "Coagulated (page does not exist)"), [Congealed](/index.php?title=Congealed&action=edit&redlink=1 "Congealed (page does not exist)"), [Solidified](/index.php?title=Solidified&action=edit&redlink=1 "Solidified (page does not exist)") |
| **Related** | [Compassion](/index.php?title=Compassion&action=edit&redlink=1 "Compassion (page does not exist)"), [Attitude](/index.php?title=Attitude&action=edit&redlink=1 "Attitude (page does not exist)"), [Foreground/Background Equanimity](/index.php?title=Foreground/Background_Equanimity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Foreground/Background Equanimity (page does not exist)"), [Rest](/index.php?title=Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rest (page does not exist)"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow"), [deep Equanimity](/index.php?title=Deep_Equanimity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Deep Equanimity (page does not exist)") |

Global Rest - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Global Rest
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Global Rest** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A quality of rest detected across the whole space of at least one sense category, even as activity may be occurring in that space.  1. Global Feel Rest means you detect some form of rest across all of Feel (for example, physical relaxation, Emotional Peace, or both, across the whole body), and you’re able to have background equanimity with any activity in Feel. Global Rest is most commonly experienced in Feel and is often accessed by relaxing individual body parts and then the whole body at once. Can also be accessed by focusing on the global absence of body sensation (i.e., the sense that your body isn’t there, which may be a brief experience, but can be profound). 2. Global Hear Rest means Rest is detected across all of Hear (i.e., both physical silence and mental quiet are detected) and you’re able to have background equanimity with any activity in Hear. 3. Global See Rest means you’re able to detect Rest across all of See (i.e., both inner and outer visual rest), and you’re able to have Background Equanimity with any activity in See.   Called Two-Way Global Rest when experienced across two sense categories and Three-Way Global Rest when experienced across all three sense categories. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Active and Restful](/index.php/Active_and_Restful "Active and Restful"), [Rest](/index.php?title=Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rest (page does not exist)"), [Emotional Peace](/index.php/Emotional_Peace "Emotional Peace"), [Virtuous Cycle](/index.php?title=Virtuous_Cycle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Virtuous Cycle (page does not exist)"), [2-Way Global Rest](/index.php?title=2-Way_Global_Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "2-Way Global Rest (page does not exist)"), [3-Way Global Rest](/index.php?title=3-Way_Global_Rest&action=edit&redlink=1 "3-Way Global Rest (page does not exist)"), [Feel Rest](/index.php/Feel_Rest "Feel Rest"), [Hear Rest](/index.php/Hear_Rest "Hear Rest"), [See Rest](/index.php/See_Rest "See Rest"), [Windows](/index.php/Windows "Windows"), [Absolute Rest](/index.php/Absolute_Rest "Absolute Rest") |

Just Note New/Gone - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Just Note New/Gone
==================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Just Note New/Gone** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A Special Exercise in the Transcend quadrant which can be thought of from two main points of view:  1. It’s commonly a warm-up for SHF Now because it can be easier to practice. Focuses on two complementary kinds of split-second Expansion/Contraction flow:  * **New:** The instant you become aware of an experience—whether the experience is beginning and you notice that as it happens, or your attention makes fresh contact with an experience that is already happening. * **Gone:** The instant you become aware that an experience is partially or completely ending, whether you’re clear about what the experience is or not.  2. It’s also a Direct Pointing technique which takes the Absolute as its focus range. While Expansion/Contraction is Space based (Contour of E/C Flow), New/Gone is time based (beginnings and endings happen *Now*).   Highlights the Absolute in the following ways:   * New points to what experience is like when there’s no friction in the sensory system (Absolute Activity). Gone points to how experience comes together and resolves into nothingness (Absolute Rest). * New and Gone are always available, which points to Timelessness. If experience is always starting and stopping at the same time, then there is no timeline. It’s always (Absolute) Now. * When New is continuous, that’s another way to understand Expansion. When Gone is continuous, that’s another way to understand Contraction. |
| **Synonyms** | [Arising/Passing](/index.php/Arising/Passing "Arising/Passing") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Gone](/index.php/Gone "Gone"), [Expansion/Contraction](/index.php?title=Expansion/Contraction&action=edit&redlink=1 "Expansion/Contraction (page does not exist)"), [Transcend (ULTRA)](/index.php?title=Transcend_(ULTRA)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcend (ULTRA) (page does not exist)"), [Special Exercise](/index.php/Special_Exercise "Special Exercise"), [SHF Now](/index.php?title=SHF_Now&action=edit&redlink=1 "SHF Now (page does not exist)"), [Direct Pointing](/index.php?title=Direct_Pointing&action=edit&redlink=1 "Direct Pointing (page does not exist)"), [Flow](/index.php/Flow "Flow") |

Recycle the Reaction - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Recycle the Reaction
====================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Recycle the Reaction** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | An important guideline and reminder to apply a CC&E strategy to work through any inner system reaction to a situation or sensory experience. Equally important to apply whether reactions happen in life (momentum practice) or during intentional practice. If you notice an inner reaction during intentional practice, whether it happens in your focus range or outside it, you can use the technique you’re working with or choose to switch techniques, either turning toward the reaction or anchoring away from it. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [ION](/index.php/ION "ION"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Strategy](/index.php/Strategy "Strategy"), [Equanimity (Foreground/Background)](/index.php?title=Equanimity_(Foreground/Background)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Equanimity (Foreground/Background) (page does not exist)"), [Self CARE](/index.php/Self_CARE "Self CARE"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Vicious and Virtuous Cycle](/index.php?title=Vicious_and_Virtuous_Cycle&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vicious and Virtuous Cycle (page does not exist)"), [Response Challenge](/index.php/Response_Challenge "Response Challenge"), [Situation Challenge](/index.php/Situation_Challenge "Situation Challenge"), [Habits](/index.php/Habits "Habits"), [Strange Experience(s)](/index.php?title=Strange_Experience(s)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strange Experience(s) (page does not exist)") |

Retreat Practice
================

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Retreat Practice** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | One of the Four Pillars. Periods of intense, continuous practice which commonly last about a week. Can be as short as four hours of unbroken intentional practice or go on for months or even years. Can be in person or online, solo or group, include contact with a teacher, or be self-guided. Typically you aim for the ideal of unbroken training, from the moment you wake up to the moment you lose consciousness in sleep. |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Four Pillars](/index.php/Four_Pillars "Four Pillars"), [Life Practice](/index.php/Life_Practice "Life Practice"), [Formal Practice](/index.php/Formal_Practice "Formal Practice"), [Self CARE](/index.php/Self_CARE "Self CARE"), [Strange Experience(s)](/index.php?title=Strange_Experience(s)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Strange Experience(s) (page does not exist)"), [Aftershock](/index.php?title=Aftershock&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aftershock (page does not exist)"), [Afterglow](/index.php?title=Afterglow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Afterglow (page does not exist)"), [Rewards](/index.php/Rewards "Rewards"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Accelerators](/index.php/Accelerators "Accelerators"), [Trait Mindfulness](/index.php/Trait_Mindfulness "Trait Mindfulness") |

Distraction - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Distraction
===========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Distraction** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | In Unified Mindfulness, a breakdown in concentration, a sensory experience outside the focus range of your technique, or an interruption, any of which could disrupt your practice if greeted unskillfully, or be helpful for your training if used skillfully. In more detail, distractions include:  1. As you practice, any moment when you detect a breakdown of concentration that affects your ability to do the technique (such as when you intend to focus on your breath and your attention gets yanked to something else, like an itch on your leg). 2. Any sensory experience that is outside the focus range of a technique, whether your attention gets pulled to it or not (such as anything in the See and Feel Sense Categories when you’re doing Just Hear). In UM, *Focus Space* includes everything in the focus range, and *Distraction Space* includes everything outside of the focus range*.* These complement each other, meaning *Focus Space* plus *Distraction Space* equals all possible sensory experience. 3. Anything that interrupts your practice session (such as falling asleep or taking an important call that causes you to drop intentional practice). |
| **Synonyms** |  |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Focus Space](/index.php/Focus_Space "Focus Space"), [Distraction Space (aka](/index.php?title=Distraction_Space_(aka&action=edit&redlink=1 "Distraction Space (aka (page does not exist)"), [Distraction Set)](/index.php?title=Distraction_Set)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Distraction Set) (page does not exist)"), [Focus Range](/index.php?title=Focus_Range&action=edit&redlink=1 "Focus Range (page does not exist)"), [Technique](/index.php/Technique "Technique"), [Foreground Impact](/index.php?title=Foreground_Impact&action=edit&redlink=1 "Foreground Impact (page does not exist)"), [Background Equanimity](/index.php?title=Background_Equanimity&action=edit&redlink=1 "Background Equanimity (page does not exist)"), [Dismissive Labeling](/index.php?title=Dismissive_Labeling&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dismissive Labeling (page does not exist)"), [Investigative Noting](/index.php?title=Investigative_Noting&action=edit&redlink=1 "Investigative Noting (page does not exist)") |

Self CARE - UMWiki















![](https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=536943829841675&ev=PageView&noscript=1)


Self CARE
=========

From UMWiki



[Jump to navigation](#mw-head)
[Jump to search](#searchInput)

| **Term** | **Self CARE** |
| --- | --- |
| **Definitions** | A way to remember the four strategies that can help you prevent integration challenges and/or integrate deep experience when you run into a challenge with that process. You may need to do one or more of these repeatedly for an extended period of time. They are:  1. **C—Create Positivity:** Nurture positive habits of behavior, emotion, aspiration, thought, and situation (Heart BEATS) (i.e., strengthening a positive "activity" of self in the free space the "somethingness" of self once occupied). 2. **A—Ask for Help:** Get support (such as from a trainer). 3. **R—Recycle the Reaction:** Turn Toward and deconstruct unpleasant reactions with Foreground Equanimity, or Anchor Away and create some space from the experience to allow for Background Equanimity. Uncomfortable reactions to the deep experience could include flatline, disorientation, fear, hopelessness, loss of meaning, or anger. 4. **E—Enjoy the Pleasant:** Selectively focus on pleasant rewards of the deep experience, such as rest, flow, bounce, spaciousness, and connectedness. |
| **Synonyms** | [The Johnny algorithm (former term)](/index.php/The_Johnny_algorithm_(former_term) "The Johnny algorithm (former term)") |
| **Antonyms** |  |
| **Related** | [Integration Strategies](/index.php?title=Integration_Strategies&action=edit&redlink=1 "Integration Strategies (page does not exist)"), [Integration](/index.php/Integration "Integration"), [Practice Maturity](/index.php/Practice_Maturity "Practice Maturity"), [Strange Experiences](/index.php/Strange_Experiences "Strange Experiences"), [Objective Behavior Check](/index.php?title=Objective_Behavior_Check&action=edit&redlink=1 "Objective Behavior Check (page does not exist)"), [Reward States](/index.php?title=Reward_States&action=edit&redlink=1 "Reward States (page does not exist)"), [Recycle the Reaction](/index.php/Recycle_the_Reaction "Recycle the Reaction"), [Deconstruct](/index.php/Deconstruct "Deconstruct"), [Turn Toward](/index.php/Turn_Toward "Turn Toward"), [Anchor Away](/index.php/Anchor_Away "Anchor Away"), [Nurture Positive](/index.php/Nurture_Positive "Nurture Positive"), [Get](/index.php?title=Get&action=edit&redlink=1 "Get (page does not exist)") [Support](/index.php/Support "Support"), [Four Pillars](/index.php/Four_Pillars "Four Pillars"), [Adverse Reactions](/index.php?title=Adverse_Reactions&action=edit&redlink=1 "Adverse Reactions (page does not exist)"), [Aftershock](/index.php?title=Aftershock&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aftershock (page does not exist)"), [Flatline](/index.php?title=Flatline&action=edit&redlink=1 "Flatline (page does not exist)"), [Insight](/index.php/Insight "Insight"), [Purification](/index.php/Purification "Purification"), [Self Coaching](/index.php?title=Self_Coaching&action=edit&redlink=1 "Self Coaching (page does not exist)"), [Trait Mindfulness](/index.php/Trait_Mindfulness "Trait Mindfulness") |
